Dama is a married woman, 55 years old, with six kids, all of whom still attend school. She lives in a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She operates a fruits and vegetables stall. She sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. She faces the challenges of competition and seasonality in her business. 

With the KSHS 30,000, she wants to purchase sacks of fruits, oranges, bananas and green vegetables for resale. She dreams of expanding and establishing a retail shop in the future.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fruits and green vegetables to sell

loans.name: Kadzo

texts.en:
Kadzo is a widowed woman and lives with her children at their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

She has operated a coconut selling business for the past three years. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned high cost of transportation to be her major challenge in the business.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase six sacks of coconuts to sale. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to purchase six sacks of coconuts to sale.

loans.name: Mildred

texts.en:
Mildred, who has one child, resides in the Kitale area where there is much poultry farming. She has been doing farming for three years. Her income comes from the sale of milk, poultry, eggs and maize. Besides farming, she has a retail business where she sells her farm products. What she enjoys most is seeing her clients being satisfied by her products.
Mildred was referred to Juhudi Kilimo by her in-law who had benefited from the Juhudi loans. He had bought dairy cows and started poultry farming. During the training, she learned that it is in saving that one reaps greater benefits. She says that through the poultry loan, she will have some eggs for her family's consumption and also for selling and the income will help her pay her child's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase poultry.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora lives in Kitale; a high poultry area. She is married, has six children, and has been farming for nine years. Her source of income comes from the sales of milk, maize, and beans. She stated that what is most enjoyable about farming is seeing her customers get satisfied by the milk she sells to them. Her biggest challenge is getting animal feeds and capital for more expansion of her dairy project.

Flora chose Juhudi Kilimo because they have been financing her agricultural projects, which have been a great success. She learned that microfinances provide financial solutions to its clients at low interest rates. This loan will help in financing the poultry project she wants to venture into. This will bring in more income to cater for her family needs.

loans.use: to purchase poultry.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman and owns a house that has piped water but not electricity.  Her greatest monthly expense is food.
 
She has operated a tailoring business for the past 4 years. She makes women suits and men suits. Her potential clients are ladies and gents. She dreams of establishing a boutique in the future. 

With the Kshs 10,000 he wants to purchase cloth material and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth material and sewing thread for her business.

loans.name: Kalama

texts.en:
Kalama, aged 32 years, is married with three school-going children. They live at their own house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

He has operated an animal-selling business, selling from home to his neighbours and passersby. He faces a major challenge of disease outbreak thus affecting his animals.

With the loan he is requesting for Kes 50,000 he wants to purchase two cows and three goats to sell. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase two cows and three goats to sell.

loans.name: Malombo

texts.en:
Malombo is a married woman and lives with her husband in their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

she has operated a firewood and charcoal-selling business for the past three years. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned the high cost of transportation to be her major challenge in the business.

With the KSHS 30,000, she wants to purchase stock of firewood and sacks of charcoal for sale. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to purchase firewood  and charcoal to sell

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia aged 23 years, is a married woman with one child who is still still very young . She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour.

loans.name: Magdaline

texts.en:
Magdaline is a hard-working woman who is struggling to meet the needs of her family from what she gets from the business of selling clothes.The previous loan helped her to purchase some clothes to sell.

Here again, Magdaline comes to you, requesting a loan of KES 40,000 to buy two bales of clothes to sell. She appreciates the support from Kiva and Yehu Microfinance Trust.

loans.use: to buy two bales of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Kavumbi

texts.en:
Kavumbi is married and has seven children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

She operates a coconuts business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Her dream is to establish a big business in the near future. 

With the KES 20,000, she wants to purchase seven sacks of coconuts for sale to get income and support her family. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase seven sacks of coconuts for sale.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma appreciates the support from Kiva and Yehu at large. Her previous loan helped her to buy a lot of fruit for selling juice. Again she comes to you requesting a loan of KES 30,000 to buy a variety of fruits so she can blend juice for sale. She thanks all who have supported her.

loans.use: to buy a variety of fruits for juicing

loans.name: Evaline

texts.en:
Evaline has been operating a clothes-selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passers-by. She faces a major challenge of stiff competition in her business. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 80,000, Evaline wants to purchase bales of clothes for both ladies and men for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and she appreciates the support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes

loans.name: Mwanamkasi

texts.en: Mwanamkasi sells a variety of foodstuffs which she has been doing to earn a living and support her family.The previous loan helped her to add to her stock thus getting additional income. Here again, she is requesting a loan of 50,000 KES. to buy potatoes, cooking oil and charcoal for the preparation of food for sale.

loans.use: to buy potatoes,  cooking oil and charcoal for the preparation of food for sale.

loans.name: Kobe

texts.en:
Kobe is a widowed woman and has been blessed with seven kids who attend school. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

She operates a fish selling business, which has been operational for over 2 years. She mentioned seasonality as a challenge in the business and she dreams of becoming a wholesaler of fish in the future. 

With the 50,000 KES she wants to purchase sacks of fish for resale. She joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fish for resale

loans.name: Florah

texts.en:
Florah is a married woman with two children who attend school. She lives in a rental house that has piped water and electricity. She cites school fees and food being her greatest monthly expenses.

She has operated a beauty salon business for the past three years. Her potential customers are her fellow neighbours and people at the market place. She dreams of earning more income and incorporating hairdressing skills in the future. 

With the Kshs 50,000 loan she wants to purchase chemicals and air conditioners for her beauty salon business. She decided to join Kiva partner Yehu to get financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase chemicals and air conditioners for her beauty salon business.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a married woman who lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She operates a business selling charcoal from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces stiff competition from other charcoal operators in this business.
 
With the 50,000 KES, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Zawadi

texts.en:
Zawadi is a single woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children since she is the breadwinner of the family.

She has operated a vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a stiff competition from other vegetable operators in her business.
 
With the 20,000 KES she wants to purchase sacks of tomatoes, potatoes, fruits, and green vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of tomatoes, potatoes, fruits, and green vegetables for resale

loans.name: Mbeyu

texts.en:
Mbeyu is a single woman who has been blessed with one child who attends school. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food and school fees. 

Mbeyu has been operating a fish selling business which has been operational for over one year. She mentioned seasonality as a challenge in the business. 

With the 20,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase two sacks of fish for resale. She joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase two sacks of fish for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a widowed woman with three children, all of whom attend school and are still under her care. They live in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for the children since she is the breadwinner of the family.

Mary has operated a clothes-selling business, which she operates at the market for town dwellers and her neighbours. She cites her major challenge to be seasonality, and she dreams of establishing a boutique in the future.

With the loan she is requesting, Mary wants to purchase two bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase two bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a married woman with three children. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She operates a food making business making comestibles like beans and chapati (flat bread) for sale to passersby and neighbours. She mentioned the high cost of purchasing foodstuffs to be her major challenge. 

With the 30,000 KES she wants to purchase food items like wheat flour, cooking fat, sugar, and beans. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a cafe in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items like wheat flour, cooking fat, sugar, and beans

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with six children, all of whom still attend school and are still under her care. They live at a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for the children.

She operates a clothes selling business, and she sells at the market to people from her town and to her neighbours. She says her major challenge is seasonality, and she dreams of establishing a boutique in the future.

With the loan she is requesting she wants to purchase three bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase three bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Franciscah

texts.en:
Franciscah is a married woman with six children, five in school and one underage. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. 

Franciscah has operated a cafe business making constables such as rice, tea, beans, chapati (flat bread) for sale to passersby and neighbors. She cited seasonality as a major challenge.

With the 40,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase stock of goods, maize flour, wheat flour, rice, and drinks for her business. Franciscah's dream is to see her children receive better education and become important people in society.

loans.use: to purchase stock of goods, maize flour, wheat flour, rice, and drinks for her business.

loans.name: Bahati

texts.en:
Bahati is a married mother of two children, all of whom attend school. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past year, Bahati has operated a clothes selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of 20,000 KES, Bahati wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Penina

texts.en: Penina appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards. She is requesting for a loan of 15,000 KES to purchase rice, beans, and maize for her business for resale. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase rice, beans, and maize for her business for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a single woman. She owns a house that has piped water but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food and fees for her one child.
 
Mary has operated a tailoring business for the past 2 years. She makes women's and men's suits. Her potential clients are ladies and gents. She dreams of establishing a boutique in the future. 

With the KES 10,000, she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is married and has been blessed with one child. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past six months, she has operated a vegetable kiosk business, selling green vegetables, tomatoes and potatoes. She sells primarily to local neighbours. She dreams of expanding and establishing a shop in the future.

With the KES 10,000 she wants to purchase sacks of cabbages, onions, potatoes and tomatoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cabbages, onions, potatoes and tomatoes.

loans.name: Safari

texts.en: Safari appreciates the support from Yehu and Kiva. He has been successful in life through his business and he is looking forward to being a great person in the future. Here again he comes to you requesting a loan of Kshs 50,000 to buy a variety of green vegetables, onions, potatoes and tomatoes in large quantity for resale.

loans.use: to buy a variety of green vegetables, onions, potatoes and tomatoes

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a single woman. She has four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her children, as she is the sole breadwinner in the family.

She has been operating a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces stiff competition from other charcoal operators in her business.
 
With the Kshs 30,000 Asha wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
Nuru is widowed and blessed with five children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her one school-going kid.

Nuru cooks food for sale at the market and sells to town dwellers and passersby. She cites price fluctuations as a challenge in the business. She dreams of establishing a café business in the future.

With this  35,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to purchase food ingredients such as beans, rice, wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, and cooking oil for the business. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase food ingredients such as beans, rice, wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, and cooking oil for the business

loans.name: Teresia

texts.en:
Teresia is married and has one child who attends school.  They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees and food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a dried fish selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition she also farms, which earns her other source of livelihood. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of becoming a major supplier of dried fish in the near future.

With the 20,000 KES (Kenyan Shillings), she wants to purchase two sacks of dried fish for resale. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase two sacks of dried fish for resale.

loans.name: Maimuna

texts.en:
Maimuna is married and has three children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for the family.

For the past three years she has operated a green grocery selling business. She sells to her neighbours and passersby. Her major challenge is seasonality of products that reduces her sales. 

With the 50,000 KES, she wants to purchase sacks of green vegetables, tomatoes and onions for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of green vegetables, tomatoes and onions for resale

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is married and has four children who are still young and go to school.  He owns a house that has neither piped water nor electricity. His greatest monthly expenses are food for the family and fees for his kids.

For over four years, he has operated a tailoring business, making garments for both men and women. He cites seasonality as his major challenge and  dreams of establishing a tailoring school in the future so that he can get more income.

With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for his business, He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for his business

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary is thankful for the support of the previous loan that helped her to buy hair chemicals, hair oil, shampoos and hair conditioners and other items for the business.  Here again she is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to add stock of hair braids, shampoo and conditioner for the business.

loans.use: to add stock of hair braids, shampoo and conditioner for the business.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose has been operating a charcoal-selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and to passersby. She faces stiff competition from other operators in the same business. Her previous loan helped her to add stock and boost her business. With the KES 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase bags of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She appreciates the support.

loans.use: to purchase bags of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a married woman with three children all under her care. They own a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She wants to start a vegetable and fruit selling business. Her major goal is to become a leading fruit vending business in the area to raise her profits.

For that reason with the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruits such as oranges, mangoes, watermelons, and pawpaws. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruits such as oranges, mangoes, watermelons, and pawpaws.

loans.name: Ezekiel

texts.en:
Ezekiel is married and has children who are still young and are going to school. He owns a house that has neither piped water nor electricity. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For over four years, he has operated a tailoring business, making garments for both men and women and also children. He cites seasonality as his major challenge.

With the KES 50,000, he wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for his business.  He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for his business.

loans.name: Maximilla

texts.en:
Maximilla is a married mother of two children who attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past three years, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of stiff competition in her business. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan of KES 20,000 that she is requesting, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Duncan

texts.en:
Duncan has been operating a shop selling foodstuffs like maize flour and cooking fat to his neighbours and passersby. He mentioned the high cost of seasonality as his major challenge and he appreciates the support from Kiva and Yehu at large.

With the KSHS 20,000, he wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, sugar, and cooking oil. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, sugar, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Mwanabibi

texts.en: Mwanabibi is a hardworking woman who works hard to ensure that her family lives well.  Here again she comes to you asking for a loan of KES 40,000 to buy skin shaving cream, shaving machine and extra brushes for her business.  She appreciates the support.

loans.use: to buy skin shaving cream, shaving machine and extra brushes for her business

loans.name: Lucas

texts.en:
Lucas is a married man with children. They live at their own house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past year, he has operated a tailoring business, operating from the market where neighbours and passersby are potential customers. He faces a major challenge of seasonality at his place of operation.

With the KES 50,000 he wants to purchase cloth materials, needles and repair his broken sewing machine.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials, needles and repair his broken sewing machine.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a married woman with one child who attends school.  She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water.

Judith has operated a beauty salon business for the past two years. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business and competition. 

With the loan, Judith wants to pay school fees for her child and add stock to her beauty salon.  She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her child and add stock to her beauty salon.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is married with four children, three of whom attend school. The fourth one is still young. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

He operates a bodaboda business, he faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business, especially when it rains.

With the KSHS 20,000, he wants to purchase spare parts for his broken motorcycle. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for his broken motorcycle.

loans.name: Jumwa

texts.en:
Jumwa is a married woman with six kids, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for the family and school fees.

She operates a grocery stall selling vegetables.  She sells at the market to town-dwellers and neighbors. She faces a challenge of high cost of transportation to her place of operation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a wholesale business in the future. 

With the 50,000 KES, she wants to buy green vegetables, 2 sacks of tomatoes, potatoes and onions to sell to get more income. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to buy green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is married with two kids. They live at a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

She operates a clothes selling business, selling from home and door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of lack of capital to expand her business.

With the loan she is requesting KES 50,000 she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Elipin

texts.en:
For the past years, Elipin has operated a clothes selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of stiff competition in her business. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 50,000 she wants to purchase bales of clothes and and bed sheets to resell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and she appreciates the support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes and and bed sheets to resell

loans.name: Riadha

texts.en:
Riadha is married with four children. They live in their own house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her one school-going kid. 

She has operated a Khanga (women's wrap cloth) selling business, selling from home and door-to-door to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of the lack of capital to expand her business.

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase bales of Khangas for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of Khangas for resale.

loans.name: Munira

texts.en:
Munira is married with four school-going children. They live at their own house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

She has operated a Khanga (womens wrap cloth) selling business, selling from home and door to door to her neighbours and passersby, and she dreams of having her own premises for the business.

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase two bales of Khangas for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase two bales of Khangas for resale.

loans.name: Mwarusi

texts.en:
Mwarusi is a business woman who is very hardworking. She is married with six children who attend school. She lives in her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. 

Mwarusi has operated a charcoal and firewood selling business for the past 4 years. Her potential clients are neighbours and passersby. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase twenty sacks of charcoal and bundles of firewood for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase twenty sacks of charcoal and bundles of firewood for resale.

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
Selina is a married woman with one child who is still under age. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past two years, she has operated a clothes business, selling second-hand clothes for men and women. She cites stiff competition as her major challenge in the business. 

Selina is requesting KES 20,000 to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She dreams of expanding to a wholesale shop in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is married woman with one child. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are for food and school fees for her child.

She operates a food making business, making staples like beans and chapati (flat bread) for sale to passersby and neighbours. She mentioned the high cost of purchasing foodstuffs as her major challenge. 

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase food items, wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar and beans. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establishing a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items, wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar and beans

loans.name: Nchijorra

texts.en:
Nchijorra is a married woman with six children, four of whom attend school, and two adults. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past six years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 50,000, she wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards. She managed to increase her monthly income through the purchase of the new motorbike for her business. 

She is requesting a loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings to pay school fees for her children. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is married with three school-going children. They live in their own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a fruit and vegetable stall business for the past two years. She sells from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a mini-greengrocer in the future.

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, tomatoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes and tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Kulthum

texts.en:
Kulthum is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family. 

For the past two years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans and sweets for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans and sweets for resale.

loans.name: Mariamu

texts.en:
Mariamu is a widow with five children, all of whom are adults. She lives at her own house that has no electricity but has piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past five years, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling from door-to-door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with six children, two of whom attend school. The rest completed. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a food stall business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase bananas, sweets, cashew nuts, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking  oil for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bananas, sweets, cashew nuts, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking  oil for resale

loans.name: Nyamvula

texts.en:
Nyamvula is a married woman. She has six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Nyamvula has operated a cereal-selling business for the past three years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of maize, beans and rice for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize, beans and rice for resale.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is married and has children. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and household consumables.

For the past year, she has operated an open-air food selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of business. 

With the KES 50,000 she wants to pay school fees for her children who attend school. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children who attend school.

loans.name: Nadzuwa

texts.en:
Nadzuwa is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a food stall business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase sweets, ground nuts, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans and cooking oil for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sweets, ground nuts, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Luvuno

texts.en:
Luvuno is married and has 12 children, five of whom attend school and the rest are adults. She operates a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and villagers. Her greatest challenge is the high cost of transportation.

Luvuno is requesting a loan from Yehu for 50,000 KES, which she will use to purchase charcoal to sell. She lives in her own house that has neither  electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal to sell

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is married, with one child. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

She operates a shop business, selling food consumables and basins at the market, to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the KES 10,000 loan, Esther wants to purchase biscuits, basins, and other consumables to sell. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase biscuits, basins, and other consumables to sell.

loans.name: Linah

texts.en:
Linah is a married woman with two children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family. 

For the past five years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase groundnuts, salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans, and sweets for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase groundnuts, salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans, and sweets for resale.

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki is a married woman. She has children, all of whom attend school. Riziki owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest  monthly expenses are food and school fees for her children.

Riziki has operated a vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a stiff competition from other vegetable operators in her business. With the 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase sacks of tomatoes, potatoes, fruits and green vegetables for resale.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of tomatoes, potatoes, fruits and green vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Mwanaiki

texts.en:
Mwanaiki is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work. She still operates a retail shop and her previous loan was a big help for her business.

She is asking for a loan to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, gallons of paraffin, eggs, detergents, maize flour and sugar for resale. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, gallons of paraffin, eggs, detergents, maize flour and sugar for resale.

loans.name: Amani

texts.en:
Amani appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

She would like to apply for a loan of KES 30,000 to buy more stock of household consumables, wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more stock of household consumables, wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar.

loans.name: Mopa

texts.en:
Mopa appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards. She is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase rice, ground nuts, and maize for resale. 

Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase rice, ground nuts, and maize for resale .

loans.name: Mjeni

texts.en: This is Mjeni. She previously accessed a loan that she used to buy more stock for her business. Her earnings were a big help for her personal, household, and business expenses.  She is requesting a loan of  20,000 KES to purchase sugar, maize flour, wheat flour, and salt for her business. She appreciates Kiva for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, maize flour, wheat flour, and salt for her business.

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en: Mwaka appreciates the previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income that she used in her small store. She would like to apply for a loan of 20,000 KES to buy more inventory of biscuits, groundnuts, sweets, soft drinks and sugar. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy inventory of biscuits, groundnuts, sweets, soft drinks and sugar

loans.name: Kwekwe

texts.en:
Kwekwe is a hardworking and enterprising woman. She is married and has seven children, six in school and one adult. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family.

For the past six years, Kwekwe has practiced farming growing various crops such as vegetables and tomatoes. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase seeds, fertilizers and pesticides for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and pesticides for her business.

loans.name: Kasichana

texts.en:
Kasichana is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work.

She is asking for a loan to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, milk, eggs, detergents, maize flour, and sugar that will help her to provide inventory for her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, milk, eggs, detergents, maize flour, and sugar for her business.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman with one child who is in school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mary operates a food business selling beans, chapati (flat bread) to passersby and neighbors. 

With the KES 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase food items such as wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar and beans. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items such as wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar and beans.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work. She is asking for a loan to buy spare parts for her grinding machine. Fatuma is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for her grinding machine

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is married and has five children; one is in school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor running water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past ten years, she has operated a poultry selling business. She sells to her neighbors and community. Her major challenges are the high cost of transportation to her place of operation.

With the 50,000 KES she wants to purchase chicks and chicken feed. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and chicken feed.

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en: Chizi is married and has two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped-in water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. For the last year, she has earned a living by selling fish at the local market to her neighbors and passersby. Her biggest challenge is the seasonality of her business. She is requesting a loan for Kshs 50,000 to buy fish, cooking oil and firewood. She decided to join Yehu get access to financial services she will use in her business

loans.use: to buy fish, cooking oil and firewood for her business

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a married woman with four children, three of whom attend school and one who is underage. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Jane's greatest monthly expense is household consumables.

For the past year, Jane has operated a business selling clothes at the market to neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high transportation costs. Jane dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

Jane will use this loan to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is married and has five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Elizabeth's greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past thirteen years, Elizabeth has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. Her major challenges are seasonality and theft. Elizabeth dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

Elizabeth plans to use this KES 50,000 loan to purchase maize flour, rice, beans and cooking  oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans and cooking  oil

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Hadija is married with seven children, all of whom attend school. They live in their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Hadija has operated a fruits and vegetable stall business for the past four years. She sells from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a mini green grocer in the future.

With the KSHS 25,000, she wants to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, and tomatoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is married and has 3 children. She lives with her husband in their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

Christine has operated a charcoal sales business for the past three years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned high transportation costs as her major business challenge.

Christine will use this KES 50,000 loan to purchase seventeen sacks of charcoal for sale. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to purchase seventeen sacks of charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Changa

texts.en:
Changa is a married woman with seven children who are adults. She lives at her own house that has neither piped water nor electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Changa has operated a cosmetic business for the past six years. Her potential customers are women. 

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase body lotion, hair oil, jewelry, chemicals and hair conditioners to sell. 

She decided to join Yehu to get financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase body lotion, hair oil, jewelry, chemicals and hair conditioners to sell.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a married woman; she has two kids, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for the family and school fees.

She operates a fruit and vegetables selling stall, she sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. She faces a challenge of the high cost of transportation to her place of operation. 

With the Kshs 30,000, she wants to purchase sacks of fruit (oranges, bananas) and green vegetables to sell. 

She dreams of expanding, and establishing a retail shop in the future.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fruit (oranges, bananas) and green vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Abigael

texts.en:
Abigael is a married woman who has one kid and owns a house that has piped water, but not electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food.
 
She has operated a tailoring business for the past three years. She makes women and men's clothes, she also repairs clothes. Her potential clients are ladies and gents. 

With the Kshs 50,000, she wants to purchase cloth materials, and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials, and sewing thread for her business.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is a married woman with eight children; one in school, and the rest are adults. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Monica operates a food-making business, making consumables like tea, rice, beans, and chapati ( flat bread) for sale to passers by and neighbours. 

With the Kshs 15,000, she wants to purchase food items such as wheat flour, charcoal, onions, cooking oil, sugar, and beans. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income, and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items such as wheat flour, charcoal, onions, cooking oil, sugar, and beans

loans.name: Mbodze

texts.en:
Mbodze is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school.  She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans and cooking  oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans and cooking  oil.

loans.name: Irine

texts.en:
Irine is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work. Beyond the vegetable grocery she operates, Irine prepares fried potatoes and sells womens' wrap cloths.

She is asking for a loan to buy cooking oil, sacks of potatoes, charcoal and bales of womens' wrap cloths for her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy cooking oil, sacks of potatoes, charcoal and bales of womens' wrap cloths for her business.

loans.name: Mesefu

texts.en:
This is Mesefu. She previously accessed a loan that she used to buy women clothes and accessories for her business. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in her family's personal, household, and business expenditures. 

Mesefu also operates a food kiosk where she sells various food.She would like to apply for a loan of 40,000 KES to buy wheat flour, maize flour, rice, beans and cooking oil for her business. She looks forward to this financial increase with happiness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, maize flour, rice, beans and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Kudura

texts.en:
Kudura is a married woman with five children, four of which are in school and one who is underage.  She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Kudura operates a food-making business, making staples like beans and chapati (flat bread) to sell to passersby and neighbors. 

With the loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase food items, wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar, charcoal and beans. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items, wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar, charcoal and beans.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en: Hellen appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian is widowed with three children who attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

She operates a shop business selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.  Her dream is to establish a wholesale business in the near future. 

With the KSHS 10,000, she wants to purchase more stock of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, and rice. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, and rice to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family thanks to her hard work.

She is asking for a loan of KSHS 20,000 to buy products such as wheat flour, milk, eggs, detergents, maize flour, and sugar. This will help her to invest back into her business, which is now in the open air. Later she will be able to lease a building for her sales.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, milk, eggs, detergents, maize flour, and sugar

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a married woman with two children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water.

She has operated a retail-selling business for the past year, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of theft in her business. 

With the loan she is requesting, Mercy would like to purchase sacks of rice, wheat flour and sugar for resale. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of rice, wheat flour and sugar for resale.

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma is a married woman with three children, two in school and one underage. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past four years, she has operated a business of selling leso (women's wraps) cloth and handbags. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding to become a big supplier of clothes in the future.

With the 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase 20 pieces of leso and 20 handbags for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 20 pieces of leso’s and 20 handbags for resale

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a very hard-working and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work.

She is asking for a loan of KES 30,000 to pay school fees for her children and to buy bales of clothes for her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children and to buy bales of clothes for her business.

loans.name: Mwanamvua

texts.en:
Mwanamvua is a married woman and she has two children, one who attends school and one who is underage. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food.

Mwanamvua operates a cereal selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality.

With the 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase sacks of maize, beans and rice for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize, beans and rice for resale

loans.name: Tola

texts.en:
Tola is married and has four children who attend school. She lives at her own house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over three years, she has been operating a beauty salon business and also sells cosmetic products. Her potential customers are neighbors and town dwellers. She dreams of incorporating her business into a beauty training school. 

With the loan that she is requesting, she wants to purchase hair extensions, lotions, hair treatments and shampoos. She joined Yehu because of their favorable loaning requirements.

loans.use: to purchase hair extensions, lotions, hair treatments and shampoos.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a single woman. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rental bills.

She has operated a boutique business, operating at the market where passersby and friends are her potential customers. She faces stiff competition from other boutique operators in her business.
 
With the Kshs 30,000 Christine wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale at her boutique shop.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale at her boutique shop.

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith is single with no children. She lives in a family house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For over two years, she has operated a fruit and vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase a stock of green vegetables, fruit, tomatoes, potatoes and onions. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of green vegetables, fruit, tomatoes, potatoes and onions.

loans.name: Biliah

texts.en:
Biliah is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rental bills, and electricity.

She has operated a kerosene-selling business for the past two years. She cites transportation costs as her major challenge. With the loan, she wants to purchase gallons of kerosene for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase gallons of kerosene for resale.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is asking for a loan because she believes that it will improve her business. Her previous loan enabled her to save money from her charcoal selling business. She is now requesting a loan of 50,000 KES to purchase 20 sacks of charcoal.

She feels that she was able to make a good investment with her previous loan, which to date has allowed her to maintain a level of profit that helps her family cover personal expenses.

loans.use: to purchase 20 sacks of charcoal for her business

loans.name: Rahel

texts.en:
Rahel operates a vegetable-selling stall. She sells at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. She faces a challenge of high cost of transportation to her place of operation. She dreams of expanding her grocery in the future to earn more income and she appreciates the support of the previous loan.

With the KES 40,000, she wants to purchase green vegetables, two crates of tomatoes, and onions for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of tomatoes, potatoes, fruits, and green vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice sells food consumables from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business and she dreams of establishing a wholesale shop business in the future as the previous loan helped her to be more established in the business. 

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 35,000, she wants to purchase additional stock of wheat flour, maize flour and beans. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and she appreciates the support from Kiva and Yehu.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of wheat flour, maize flour and beans.

loans.name: Perice

texts.en:
Perice is a married woman who has kids. She lives at a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a Kiosk business, selling from home to her neighbours and passers-by. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business.

With the loan that she is requesting of 30,000 KES, she wants to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize flour and beans. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize flour and beans

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose operates a tailoring business and she makes women suits and men suits. Her potential clients are ladies and gents.The previous loan helped her to purchase cloth materials and threads for the business. 

With the KES 25,000 she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business and she appreciates the support.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing thread for her business.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther appreciates the previous loans she has received, which have helped her to grow her business of rearing chickens. The loans have helped her to buy chicks and their feed and out of the sales she gets money to boost the living standards of her family. Here again she comes to you requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to buy medicine for the chicks, because there is an outbreak of diseases in this season.

loans.use: to buy medicine for her chicks

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en: Hadija works her poultry business which helps her to take care of her family.  The previous loan helped her to buy more chicks for her business.  Here again she comes to you requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to buy feed for her chicken and also buy medicine for the chicks to protect them from diseases. She appreciates the support.

loans.use: to buy feed for her chicken and medicine for her chicks

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is married and has school-going children. They live at their own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a fruits and vegetable stall business for the past 2 years. She sells from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a mini green grocer in the future.

With the 25,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) she wants to pay school fees for her daughter who attends Eldoro Girls Taveta. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her daughter who attends Eldoro Girls Taveta.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a married woman who owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her kids.

For the past four years, she has operated a retail kiosk business selling household consumables like wheat flour, rice and cooking oil. She cites seasonality as her major challenge in the business. 

She is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to boost her kiosk business by purchasing bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat to sell. She dreams of expanding to a wholesale shop in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a mother and has children; her kids still attend school which is the reason for her hard work.  She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. 

She has operated a cereals business at the market for the past two years, selling to passersby and neighbours. She cited seasonality as her major challenge in the business.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase sacks of maize, beans, rice, and also sugar. Her dream is to see her children get a better education and become important people in their society.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize, beans, rice, and also sugar.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a married woman with children, all of whom attend school. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past two years, selling consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour to stock for sale in her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour to stock and sell

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet is making both ends meet in life by making and selling home-made soap and selling detergents. The previous loan helped her to buy detergents for the preparation of the same. Here again she comes to you, requesting a loan of Kshs 25,000 to buy the required detergents for home-made soap for sale. She appreciates the support.

loans.use: to buy the required detergents for home-made soap for sale.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine operates a cereals shop business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. 

With the loan that she is requesting of Kes 30,000, she wants to purchase stock of wheat, maize, beans and rice grains for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of wheat, maize, beans and rice grains for sale

loans.name: Soghona

texts.en:
Soghona is a married woman with one child who attends school and is under her care. She lives in a rental house that neither has electricity nor piped water. 

For over three years, she has operated a business selling clothes from door to door and from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase a bale of khangas or lesos (traditional Kenyan garments) for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a bale of khangas or lesos (garments) for resale.

loans.name: Salima

texts.en: Salima appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. Salima also operates her rental houses in addition to the food stall business. She is requesting a loan of 43,575 KES to purchase roofing items for her rental houses. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase roofing items for her rental houses

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a married woman with four school going children. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past seven years, she has operated a business of selling lesos (women's wraps). She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding to become a big supplier of clothes in the future.

With the Kshs 60,000 she wants to purchase 40 pieces of lesos (women's wraps) for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 40 pieces of lesos (women's wraps)  for resale

loans.name: Tima

texts.en:
Tima is married with two children, one goes to school and the other is an adult.  She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. 

Tima has operated a cafe business making stables like rice, tea, beans and chapati (flat bread) for sale to passersby and neighbours. She cited seasonality  as a major challenge.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase stock of goods including maize flour, wheat flour, rice and drinks for the business. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of goods such as maize flour, wheat flour, rice and drinks for the business

loans.name: Shumi

texts.en:
Shumi is a hardworking and enterprising woman. She is married with four children, all of whom are adults. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Shumi cooks fried potatoes that she sells to neighbors and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge. With the KES 70,000 she wants to purchase a sack of potatoes and cooking oil. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and to establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase a sack of potatoes and cooking oil.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work.

She is asking for a loan of KSH.50,000 to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, milk, eggs, onions, tomatoes, maize flour, and sugar that will help her to invest back into her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, milk, eggs, onions, tomatoes, maize flour, and sugar for her business

loans.name: Sikukuu

texts.en:
This is Sikukuu. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to purchase more items for her business. She has been in this business for years now, and it keeps on growing. 

She would like to apply for a loan, this time for 20,000 Kshs to buy more sacks of potatoes, cooking oil, and firewood for her business.She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of potatoes, cooking oil, and firewood for her business

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a married woman. She has three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food.

Mwanajuma operates a cereal selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality.

With the KES 40,000, she wants to purchase sacks of maize, beans, and rice for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize, beans, and rice for resale.

loans.name: Mishi

texts.en:
Mishi is a married woman with no children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past year, she has operated a business selling leso (a woman's wrap) cloth. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding to become a big supplier of clothes in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, she wants to purchase more pieces of lesos for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more pieces of lesos (women's wraps) for resale.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is married with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past two years, she has operated a food kiosk business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 35,000 loan, she wants to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, cooking  oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, cooking  oil.

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija is married with two children, one in school and one who is still underage. They live in a rented house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Khadija has operated a clothes-selling business for the past five years. She sells in a shop to town dwellers, passersby and neighbors. She faces a major challenge of inflation in her business. 

With the KSHS 30,000, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu is a widowed woman and has five children. Two attend school and the rest are adults. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food 

She has operated a fish-selling business for the last three years, selling at the market to her neighbors’ and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the KES 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase fish, cooking oil, and firewood for her business. She decided to join Yehu to acquire financial services for her business

loans.use: to purchase fish, cooking oil, and firewood for her business

loans.name: Langoni

texts.en: Langoni appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. Still operating a food stall that prepares and sells various foods, she is requesting a new loan of Ksh.50,000 to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil and green peas. Langoni thanks Yehu for its financial support.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil and green peas for her business.

loans.name: Bintihamis

texts.en:
This is Bintihamis. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to purchase more coconuts for her business. Beside the coconut selling business, she also sells fried fish.

She would like to apply for a loan of KES 50,000 to buy more fish, cooking oil and firewood for her business. 

Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy more fish, cooking oil and firewood for her business.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is married and has two children, who go to school. She lives in her own house that has neither piped water nor electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

Fatuma has operated a cosmetics business for the past two years. Her potential customers are women. Fatuma plans to use this KES 15,000 loan to purchase body lotion, hair oil, jewelry, chemicals and hair conditioners for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase body lotion, hair oil, jewelry, chemicals and hair conditioners for resale.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
This is Mariam. Her previous loan was a big help with her business. She was able to buy more items for her kiosk shop. She has been in this business for years now, and it keeps on growing. 

She would like to apply for a loan of 40,000 KES to buy more stock of household consumables such as sweets, maize flour, soft drinks, rice and sugar for resale. The more items displayed at the kiosk, the better. 

 Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs.  She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy more stock of household consumables such as sweets, maize flour, soft drinks, rice and sugar for resale

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
This is Mwanajuma. She previously accessed a loan that she used to purchase a new sewing machine for her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. 
Beside the tailoring business, Mwanajuma sells coconuts to her neighbors.

She would like to apply for  Kshs 40,000 loan to buy more coconuts for her business. Her profit from her business will definitely help her to provide for her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with happiness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy more coconuts for her business.

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a married woman with one child who goes to school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. For the past seventeen years, she has operated a food stall business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenge. 

With the 50,000 KES loan she wants to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en:
Hadija is married with seven school going children. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Hadija has operated a fish selling business at the market for the past five years, selling to town dwellers and neighbors. She faces a major challenge in high cost of purchasing fish, especially during periods of cold currents in the deep sea. 

Hadija is requesting for a loan to purchase bundles of fish, cooking oil and firewood. She decided to join Yehu to access loans at a lower cost to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of fish, cooking oil and firewood.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is married with five school going children. They live at their own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mariam has operated a fruit and vegetable stall business for the past three years. She sells from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a mini green grocer in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, tomatoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial supports.

loans.use: to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Bintikhalfani

texts.en:
Bintikhalfani is a hardworking and enterprising woman who is married with two school going children. She lives in her own house that has electricity but not piped water.

Bintikhalfani has operated a cashew nut selling business at the market for the past twenty years, selling to passersby and neighbors. She cited seasonality as her major challenge in the business.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase sacks of cashews for resale.She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cashews for resale

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
