Mwanaisha is a divorced mother of five school going children.She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwanaisha has operated a cashew selling business at the market for the past ten years, selling to passersby and neighbors. She cited seasonality as her major challenge in the business.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase 5 sacks of cashews and use the rest of the money for transportation costs. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 5 sacks of cashews and use the rest of the money for transportation costs

loans.name: Bidala

texts.en:
This is Bidala. She is a married woman with seven children. Two are in school and five are adults. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Bidala has operated a cashew nut selling business at the market for the past ten years, selling to passersby and neighbours. She cited seasonality as her major challenge in the business.

With the KES 50,000 loan, she wants to purchase seven sacks of cashew nuts for resale. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase seven sacks of cashew nuts for resale.

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en:
Chizi is a married woman with nine children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a kiosk shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans and cooking oil for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Ngula

texts.en:
Ngula is a married woman with no children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans and sweets for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans and sweets for resale.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is a married woman with four school-going children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family. 

For the past 10 years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans, and sweets to sell. 

She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans, and sweets to sell.

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
Mwaka is a hardworking and enterprising woman who owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. She is married with seven children all of whom are school.

Mwaka sells goat meat to various butcheries and hotels. She has been in this business for the past six years. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase more goats for her business. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more goats for her business.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past four years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans and cooking oil for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Saumu

Saumu is a hardworking and enterprising woman who is married with five children all of whom go to school. Saumu sells cashews at the market. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

She is requesting for a loan of ksh.10,000 to pay school fees for her children. She looks forward for a financial support with gladness and a thankful heart.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

Christabel is married woman with one child who goes to school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past one year, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase sugar, wheat flour, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice and cooking oil for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, wheat flour, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice and cooking oil for resale.

Nadzua is married woman with seven children. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food.

loans.name: Njira

texts.en:
Njira is a widowed woman who is an adult. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase salt, cashew nuts, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans and sweets for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

For the past six years, she has operated a business of selling leso (women's wrap) cloth. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding to become a big supplier of clothes in the future.

She wants to purchase 40 pieces of Leso for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 40 pieces of Leso (women's wrap)  for resale

loans.name: Umazi

Umazi operates a cereal selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality.

With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase sacks of maize, beans, and rice for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize, beans, and rice for resale.

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
Mwaka is a married woman with two children, one in school and one who is still underage. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a kerosene selling business for the past ten years.  She cites transportation costs as her major challenge.

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase gallons of kerosene for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase gallons of kerosene for resale.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is asking for a loan because she believes that through it she will be able to improve her business. The previous loan enabled her to save money from her retail shop. 

She is requesting a loan of 25,000 KES to purchase rice, cooking oil, maize flour, wheat flour, beans, and sugar for her business.

Anna feels that she was able to make a good investment with her previous loan. The previous loan allowed her to maintain her level of profits to help her family cover their personal expenses

loans.use: to purchase rice, cooking oil, maize flour, wheat flour, beans, and sugar.

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a hardworking and enterprising woman who thanks Kiva for their loan funding program that improved her fish selling business.

She is requesting a loan of 15,000 KES to buy nails and iron sheets and to pay the labor costs for the construction of a new roof top for her house.

Mejumaa looks forward to the financial support with gladness and a thankful heart.

loans.use: to buy nails and iron sheets and to pay for the labor costs for a new roof.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
This is Mwanakombo. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to add more stock to her general store. She has been in this business for years now, and it keeps on growing.

Beside the general store, Mwanakombo operates a motorbike business. She would like to apply for another loan, this time for 50,000 KES, through Yehu to buy a new motorbike for her business. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs.

Mwanakombo looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy a new motorbike for her business.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima appreciates her previous loan through Yehu which enabled her to increase profits in her fish selling business. She is now applying for a 50,000 KES loan to buy more fish, cooking oil and charcoal to sell. She appreciates Kiva and Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy fish, cooking oil and charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Zuhura

texts.en: Zuhura appreciates her previous loan, which improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She would like to apply for a loan of KSHS 50,000 to buy more stock of household consumables, wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more stock of household consumables, wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar.

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
Mwaka is married and has four children, all of whom go to school. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

Mwaka has operated a coconut-selling business for the past six years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase two sacks of coconuts for resale and pay for her transportation costs to her place of operation. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase coconuts for resale and pay transportation costs

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is married and has nine children, four of whom attend school. The rest are adults. Her husband is a businessman and he contributes to the family's basic needs.

Mwanamisi has operated a coconut-selling business for the past 13 years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase sacks of coconuts for resale and pay for transportation costs. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of coconuts for resale and pay transportation costs

loans.name: Kadzo

Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase onions, tomatoes, vegetables and potatoes for resale.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:

For the past two years, she has operated a kiosk shop business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KSHS 30,000, she wants to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell in her kiosk

Nrika has sold fish at the market for the last two years, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.

Nrika decided to join Yehu to obtain financial help for her business. She is applying for a 20,000 KES loan to buy fish, cooking oil and firewood for her business.

loans.use: to buy fish, cooking oil and firewood

loans.name: Kanzingo

She is asking for a loan to buy more items such as wheat flour, milk, eggs, detergents, maize flour, and sugar to help her to invest back into her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell

loans.name: Anzazi

She would like to apply for a loan of KSHS 15,000 to buy more stock of beans, wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more stock of beans, wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar.

loans.name: Margaret

Beside the coconut selling business, she wants to start selling water. She is requesting a loan of KSHS 50,000 to purchase a water tank for her business. She looks forward to financial support with gladness and a thankful heart.

loans.name: Khadijah

Khadijah sells household items, selling such items cutlery, plates, cups, basins, carpets, ropes, and baskets, among others.

With this 80,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase more stock of household items such as kitchen utensils, carpets, and ropes for her business. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of household items such as kitchen utensils, carpets, and ropes

loans.name: Esther

For the past 10 years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 80,000, she wants to purchase detergent, maize flour, sugar, rice, beans, and cooking  oil. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

With the KSHS 20,000, she wants to purchase detergents, maize flour, wheat flour, salt, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans, and sweets for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

She joined Yehu Microfinance Trust in order to gain access to funds. She is requesting a loan of  KES 25,000 to purchase more goats for her business.

loans.name: Umazi

For the past four years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 50,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase soap, kerosene, wheat flour, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing threads for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing threads for her business.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

With the Kshs (Kenyan Shillings) 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions for resale.

Anzazi is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past two years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil for resale.

Meswalehe has operated a coconut selling business for the past four years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With the loan she is requesting she wants to purchase two sacks of coconuts for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

She thanks Yehu for its financial support.

Kamwana has operated a fruits-and-vegetables stall business for the past one year. She sells from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a mini green grocery in the future.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes and tomatoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes and tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Vinani

Vinani prepares dumplings using sugar, cooking oil, and wheat flour and sells to neighbors and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With the KSHS 10,000, she wants to purchase wheat flour, sugar and cooking oil for her business. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.name: Nchanze

Nchanze is a widowed woman with four children, all of whom are adults. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

With the KSHS 20,000, she wants to purchase soap, wheat flour, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase soap, wheat flour, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Saumu

Saumu has operated a vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces stiff competition from other vegetable operators.
 
With the 10,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase sacks of tomatoes, potatoes, fruits and green vegetables for resale.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of tomatoes, potatoes, fruits and green vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Adija

texts.en:
Adija is married woman with three children, all of whom attend school.  She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past ten years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby.  She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenge.  She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 50,000 loan, she wants to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, cooking  oil.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, cooking  oil.

loans.name: Muhi

Muhi is a married woman with one child who is still underage. She lives in her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expense is food

She has operated a kerosene selling business for the past two years.  She cites transportation costs as her major challenge.  With the loan, she is requesting she wants to purchase more kerosene for resale.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase kerosene for resale

loans.name: Mishi

For over two years, she has operated a fruit and vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passers-by. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With this loan of KES 20,000 she wants to purchase stock for resale: green vegetables, fruit, tomatoes, potatoes and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.name: Margaret

She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase onions, tomatoes, vegetables and potatoes to resell.

loans.name: Racheal

texts.en:
Racheal is a widowed woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past six years, she has operated a mobile charging business. She says that power failure is her major challenge. 

With the KES 25,000 she wants to purchase power extensions and mobile chargers. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase power extensions and mobile chargers.

loans.name: Anzazi

Anzazi sells goat meat to various butcheries and hotels. She has been in this business for the past five years. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase more goats for her business. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more goats for her business.

loans.name: Fatuma

Fatuma is a married woman with no children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past one year, she has operated a business of selling leso (women's wrap) cloth. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding to become a big supplier of clothes in the future.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase 40 pieces of lesos for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.name: Mwanaulu

Mwanaulu operates a food making business, making constables like beans and chapati( flat bread) for sale to passersby and neighbours. 

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase food items such as wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar and beans. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.name: Mejumaa

Besides her business of renting out her handcarts, she also sells lesso (women's wrap clothes). She is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase more pieces of lesso clothes for resale. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.name: Fatuma

Fatuma has operated a charcoal-selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and villagers. Her greatest monthly challenge is the high cost of transportation.

She is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase charcoal for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

She feels that she was able to make a good investment with her previous loan, which to date has allowed her to maintain her level of profits to help her family cover their personal expenses.

Fatuma appreciates her previous loan that enabled her to get profits she used in her fish selling business.

She is requesting a loan of KES 40,000 to purchase more stock of fish for her business. She appreciates Kiva and Yehu for their financial support.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity, but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 25,000, Mwanaisha wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans that will boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, cooking  oil.

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is married with four school-going children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwanajuma has operated a fish-selling business at the market for the past three years, selling to town dwellers and neighbors. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of purchasing fish, especially when cold currents prevail in the deep sea. 

Mwanajuma is requesting a loan to purchase bundles of fish, cooking oil and firewood. She decided to join Yehu to access loans at lower cost to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of fish, cooking oil and firewood.

loans.name: Saum

texts.en:
Saum is married and has two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

She has operated a fish-selling business for the last year, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase fish, cooking oil, and firewood for her business. She decided to join to acquire financial support for her business.

loans.use: to purchase fish, cooking oil, and firewood for her business.

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a married woman. She has one child who goes to school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest  monthly expenses are food and rental bills.

Eunice operates a business selling grains and other foods, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality.

With the KES 15,000 she wants to purchase sacks of maize, beans, peas, rice for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize, beans, peas, and rice for resale.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is still single with no children. She lives in a rental house that has no piped water but has electricity. 

Elizabeth has operated a cosmetic business for the past year. Her potential customers are women. 

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase body lotion, hair oil, jewelry, chemicals and hair conditioners for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase body lotion, hair oil, jewelry, chemicals and hair conditioners for resale

loans.name: Mwanakesi

texts.en:
Mwanakesi is a married mother of two children, both of whom go to school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.
 
Mwanakesi has operated a milk-selling business at the market for the past two years, selling to passersby and neighbours. She cited seasonality as her major challenge in the business.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase gallons of milk for resale. Her dream is to see her children get better education and become important people in their society.

loans.use: to purchase gallons of milk for resale.

loans.name: Mwanalima

texts.en:
Mwanalima is a married woman with one child, who attends school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past year, she has operated a food stall business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 20,000, she wants to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans and cooking oil for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is asking for a loan because she believes that it will help her to improve her business 

The previous loan enabled her to save money from her business. She is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase more women's wrap clothing (khangas) for her business.

Fatuma feels that she was able to make a good investment with her previous loan, which to date has allowed her to maintain her level of profits to help her family cover their personal expenses.

loans.use: to purchase more women's wrap clothing (khangas) for her business.

loans.name: Mesalimu

texts.en:
Mesalimu is married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past two years, Mesalimu has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 50,000, she wants to purchase wheat, flour, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat, flour, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia is a single woman with no children. She still lives in her family's house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.
 
Sophia has operated a cosmetics business for the past year. Her potential customers are women. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuations in her business. 

With the 20,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase body lotions, hair oil, jewellery, chemicals, and hair conditioners for resale. 

Sophia decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to get financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase body lotions, hair oil, jewellery, chemicals, and hair conditioners for resale.

loans.name: Siti

texts.en:
Siti is single and with lives at her family house that has no piped water but has electricity.  She operates a cosmetic business, which she has been doing for one year. Her potential customers are women. 

Siti is requesting a loan from Yehu for 20,000 KES, which she will use to purchase body lotion, hair oil, jewelry chemicals, and hair conditioners to sell. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase body lotion, hair oil, jewelry chemicals, and hair conditioners to sell

loans.name: Biasha

texts.en:
Biasha is married with two children, one in school and one underage. They live at their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Biasha has operated a fruits and vegetables stall business for the past two years. She sells from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a mini-greengrocery in the future.

With the KES 20,000, she wants to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, and tomatoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, and tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu is a married woman with one child who is still underage. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past year, she has operated a business selling khangas (women's wraps). She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding to become a big supplier of clothes in the future.

With the 20,000 KES she wants to purchase 40 pieces of khangas (women's wraps) for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 40 pieces of khangas (women's wraps)  for resale.

loans.name: Mwanajaa

texts.en:
Mwanajaa is married and has three children, two of whom attend school. She makes soft drinks and ice cubes using fruits and juice flavor and sells them  to her neighbors and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

Mwanajaa is requesting a loan from Yehu, which she will use to purchase juice flavors and fruits for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She lives in her own house that has electricity but not piped water.

loans.use: to purchase juice flavors and fruits for her business

loans.name: Fridah

texts.en:
Fridah is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are household consumables and school fees.

For the past 10 years, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling at the market. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Maryyam

texts.en:
Maryyam is a married woman with one child who is still underage. She lives in her own house that has no piped water but does have electricity. 

Maryyam has operated a cosmetics business for the past two years. Her potential customers are women. 

With the KSHS 20,000, she wants to purchase braids, weaves, hair chemicals, hair oil, shampoos and hair conditioners for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase braids, weaves, hair chemicals, hair oil, shampoos and hair conditioners for resale

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is a married woman with two children, one of whom attends school and one of whom is underage. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past three years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 15,000 she wants to purchase salt, bread, maize flour, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans, and sweets for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase salt, bread, maize flour, soft drinks, rice, sugar, beans, and sweets for resale.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

She is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale. She thanks Yehu for its financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is asking for a loan because she believes that through it she will improve her business.

The previous loan enabled her to save money from her retail shop business. She is requesting a loan of KES 10,000 to purchase maize flour, wheat flour, rice, cooking oil for her business.

She feels that she was able to make a good investment with her previous loan, which to date has allowed her to maintain her level of profits to help her family cover their personal expenses.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, wheat flour, rice, and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Binti

texts.en:
Binti is a married woman with six children,all of whom go to school.She lives in her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water.Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Binti has operated a cashew nut selling business at the market for the past twelve years, selling to passersby and neighbors. She cited seasonality as her major challenge in the business. With the 25,000 KES she wants to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale. She joined Yehu to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards.

She is requesting a loan of KES 30,000 to purchase gallons of paraffin for resale. 

Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase gallons of paraffin for resale.

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is a married woman with four children who all go to school. She lives in her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a kerosene-selling business for the past three years. She cites transportation costs as her major challenge.

With the loan, she is requesting she wants to purchase gallons of kerosene for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase gallons of kerosene for resale.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a very hardworking and enterprising woman. She says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family thanks to her hard work.

She is asking for a new loan to purchase more bales of clothes for her business. 

She is grateful for all the support she has received.

loans.use: to purchase more bales of clothes for her business.

loans.name: Mwanaidi

texts.en:
Mwanaidi is a married woman with two children, who both attend school. Mwanaidi lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwanaidi has operated a kerosene selling business for the past two years. She cites transportation costs as her major challenge. With this loan of KES 30,000 that she is requesting, she wants to purchase gallons of kerosene for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase gallons of kerosene for resale.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en:
Mwanamisi is a hardworking and enterprising woman. She is a married mother of four children who are in school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwanamisi prepares dumplings using sugar, cooking oil, and wheat flour and sells them to neighbors and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge. With this KES 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase wheat flour, sugar, and cooking oil for her business. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, sugar, and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Jonsy

texts.en:
Jonsy is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past four years, Jonsy has operated an egg selling business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality as her major challenge. With this KES 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase more crates of eggs for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more crates of eggs for resale.

loans.name: Chacha

texts.en: This is Chacha. She previously accessed a loan that she used to buy more stock of charcoal for her business. Her earnings were a big help for her personal, household and business expenditures. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) to purchase more sacks of charcoal for her business. She appreciates Kiva for its financial support

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of charcoal for her business

loans.name: Khabukwi

texts.en:
Khabukwi is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work. Beside her clothes-selling business, Khabukwi sells poultry.

She is asking for a loan to buy more chicks and chicken feed for her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy more chicks and chicken feed for her business.

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en: Mwanajuma appreciates her previous loan, which improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income from her business. She would like to apply for a loan of Ksh 22,760 to pay school fees for her children. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Mebakari

texts.en: This is Mebakari. She previously accessed a loan that she used to purchase more dried fish for resale. Her earnings were a big help for her personal, household, and business expenditures. She still sells fish. She is requesting a loan of KSh 25,000 to pay school fees for her children. She appreciates Kiva for their financial support.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en: Mejumaa appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She would like to apply for a loan of KSh 50,000 to buy more stock of cooking oil, wheat flour and sugar for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more stock of cooking oil, wheat flour and sugar for her business.

loans.name: Bendera

texts.en:
Bendera is a widowed woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over eight years, she has operated a fruit and vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions.

loans.name: Bintihamisi

texts.en:
Bintihamisi is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work.

She is asking for a loan to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, milk, maize flour and sugar that will help her to invest back into her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, milk, maize flour and sugar.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past four years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase groundnuts, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase groundnuts, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Nimaneno

texts.en:
Nimaneno appreciates her previous loan for improving her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income from selling charcoal.

Apart from her charcoal selling business, Nimaneno sells lessos (cloth for women's wraps). She would like to apply for a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more pieces of lessos for resale. 

She thanks Yehu for its financial support.

loans.use: to buy more pieces of lessos (cloth for women's wraps) for resale

loans.name: Meselemani

texts.en:
Meselemani, who is a very hardworking and enterprising woman, managed to earn good profits from her firewood business and opened up a new business preparing dumplings. She thanks Kiva lenders for making this happen.

She also operates the firewood-selling business.

She would like to apply for a loan of ksh 40,000 to buy more bundles of firewood, wheat flour, cooking oil and sugar for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more bundles of firewood, wheat flour, cooking oil and sugar for her business.

loans.name: Mwanaharusi

texts.en:
Mwanaharusi thanks Kiva lenders for their financial support that has greatly improved her living standards and her juice business.

Mwanaharusi wants to repair her business premises. She is requesting a loan of KES 20,000 to purchase cement, nails and blocks and pay for labor costs. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase cement, nails and blocks and pay for labor expenses.

loans.name: Njira

texts.en:
Njira appreciates Kiva lenders for her previous loan that improved her living standard and enabled her to generate more profits. She is requesting a loan of KES 30,000 to purchase more tomatoes, vegetables, and potatoes for her business.

Nijira looks forward to financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of vegetables to resell.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha thanks Kiva lenders for supporting her business financially and enabling her to generate profits that she used to start a business of preparing fried potatoes.

She is requesting a loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase potatoes, cooking oil and charcoal for her business.

loans.use: to purchase potatoes, cooking oil and charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Bintijuma

texts.en:
Bintijuma is a married woman with one child who goes to school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a business of selling leso (women's wrap) cloth. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of expanding to become a big supplier of clothes in the future.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase 20 pieces of lesos for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 20 pieces of lesos (women's wrap clothing) for resale.

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris operates a shop kiosk business to earn an income. She has operated her business for the past 10 years. She sells her wares to members of the community and to passers-by. She mentions price fluctuation as her major business challenge.

Doris and her husband have five grown children. Their house has neither electricity nor piped water. Their greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

She decided to join Yehu to get financial support for her business. With her Kshs 40,000 loan funds, she intends to purchase maize flour, wheat flour, cooking oil, kerosene, and sugar.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, wheat flour, cooking oil, kerosene, and sugar

loans.name: Phoebe

texts.en:
Phoebe appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

Besides operating a mobile charging and electronic shop, she also operates a grocery kiosk. She is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase sugar, rice and cooking fats for resale. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, rice and cooking fats for resale.

loans.name: Kanga

texts.en:
Kanga is a divorced woman who has been blessed with four children; one is in school and the rest are adults. She lives at her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Kanga operates a firewood-selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and villagers. Her greatest monthly challenge is the high cost of transportation.

She is requesting for a loan of KES 15,000 to purchase more bundles of firewood for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more bundles of firewood for resale.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth earns an income as a fish vendor. She joined Yehu to boost her business. Her previous loan was a big help to her fish selling business, and she managed to improve her living standards as a result. She thanks her Kiva lenders for their financial support.

In addition to her fish vending business, Elizabeth operates a kiosk shop. She is requesting a loan in the amount of KSH 25,000 in order to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil, rice, and beans to offer for sale.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil, rice, and beans to offer for sale

loans.name: Nguphi

texts.en:
Nguphi runs a fruit and vegetable stall to earn an income. She sells her wares from her home to members of her community. She has been engaged in this business for the past four years. 

She and her husband have two children, one grown and one still in school. Their house has neither electricity nor piped water. The family's primary monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Nguphi joined Yehu to receive financial support for her business. With her Kshs 30,000 loan funds, she will purchase green vegetables, potatoes, and tomatoes to offer for sale. 

She dreams of establishing a mini green-grocer in the future.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables, potatoes, and tomatoes to offer for sale

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is married, and has five school age children who are all attending school.  She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a poultry selling business.  She sells to her neighbours and passersby.  Her major challenges are the high cost of transportation to her place of operation.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase more chicks for her business.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase more chicks for her business.

loans.name: Marieta

texts.en:
Marieta is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over four years, she has operated a fruits and vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase a stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes and potatoes for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes and potatoes for her business.

loans.name: Mlongo

texts.en:
Mlongo is a married woman with five children, four in school and one adult. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family. 

For the past five years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KSh 50,000 loan she wants to purchase sugar, maize flour, wheat flour, cooking fats, soap, and detergents for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, maize flour, wheat flour, cooking fats, soap, and detergents for resale.

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en:
Zainabu is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past two years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KSh 20,000 she wants to purchase cooking oil, wheat flour, and maize flour for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cooking oil, wheat flour, and maize flour for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase maize flour, cooking oil, wheat flour and sugar for her business.

loans.name: Nadzuwa

texts.en:
Nadzuwa is married woman with nine children, six of whom attend school, while three are adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past five years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase add more stock of sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans and cooking  oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans and cooking  oil.

loans.name: Tambuu

texts.en:
Tambuu is married and has six children, all of whom attend school. She lives at her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are household consumables and school fees.

For over seven years, she has been running a tailoring business, making garments for both men and women, and curtains. She says that seasonality is her major challenge. 

With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing threads for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing threads for her business

loans.name: Nyadzuwa

texts.en:
Nyadzuwa is 46 years of age. She is a widowed woman with four children: two adults and two of whom attend school.  She owns a house that has neither electricity, nor piped water. 

Nyadzuwa has operated a cafe business making constables like, rice, tea, beans, chapati( flat bread) for sale to passersby and neighbours. She has cited seasonality as her major challenge.

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase stock of food ingredients, maize flour, wheat flour, rice, onions, tomatoes for the business. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of food ingredients, maize flour, wheat flour, rice, onions, tomatoes for the business.

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en:
Chizi is a married woman who has been blessed with five children, one in school and the rest adults. She lives at her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Chizi has operated a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and villagers. Her greatest monthly challenge is the high cost of transportation.

Chizi is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase charcoal for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
This is Mwanasha. Her previous loan was a big help to her business. She was able to purchase more stock for her business.  
She would like to apply for a loan of ksh. 30,000 to buy more maize flour, tea leaves, beans, sugar, cooking oil and rice for her business. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy stocks of maize flour, tea leaves, beans, sugar, cooking oil and rice for her business.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a hardworking and enterprising woman who owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. She is a married woman with three school-going children. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family.

Halima sells goat meat at the market. She has been in this business for the past seven years. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With the 50,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase more goats for her business. She joined Yehu to boast her business.

loans.use: to purchase more goats for her business

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a hardworking and enterprising woman who lives in the Coastal Region of Kenya.

Mwanajuma has operated a coconut selling business for the past three years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. 

With the loan, she wants to purchase 2 sacks of coconuts to resell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 2 sacks of coconuts to resell.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is a hardworking woman who thanks Kiva lenders for her previous loan funds, which boosted her fish vending business. Besides the fish vending business, Elizabeth also operates a vegetable stall. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase tomatoes, onions, vegetables and potatoes for resale. She joined Yehu for financial support.

loans.use: to purchase tomatoes, onions, vegetables and potatoes for resale.

loans.name: Kalunda

texts.en:
Kalunda lives in the coastal region of Kenya. She has been operating a clothes-selling business, selling various women's and men's clothes. 

Kalunda is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase women's wrap clothes, cloth materials, and men's clothes to resell. She joined Yehu Microfinance Trust to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase women's wrap clothes, cloth materials, and men's clothes to resell.

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian is married and has seven children, four of whom are in school and three are underage. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a mat weaving business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality as her major challenge in the business.

With the 20,000 KES she wants to purchase bundles of reefs for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of reefs for her business

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam appreciates  her previous loan that improved her living standards.  Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.
 
She would like to apply for a loan of 20,000 KES to buy more goats for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more goats for her business

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki is married with three children, all of whom go to school. They live in their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Riziki has operated a juice making business for the past two years. She sells from home to her neighbors. 

With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase sacks of passion fruits, carrots and sugar for her business. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of passion fruits, carrots and sugar for her business

loans.name: Marium

texts.en:
Marium lives in the coastal region of Kenya. She is a married woman with eight adult children. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

Marium has a store in her house in which she stocks and sells makuti (thatching materials made from palm leaves). She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.

She is requesting a loan to purchase more makuti for resale. She expects to do this without any difficulties and to continue working without any problems.

loans.use: to purchase more makuti (thatching material) for resale.

loans.name: Mealii

texts.en: Mealii is a hardworking and enterprising woman who lives in the coastal region of Kenya. Her previous loan was a big help to her clothes-selling business. She is requesting a loan of KSh 40,000 to purchase iron sheets to construct her house. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase iron sheets to construct her house

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is married and has two children, both of whom go to school.  She lives in her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water.

Rehema has operated a fruit selling business for the past five years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. 

With the loan she is requesting she wants to purchase bananas, oranges, and coconuts for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bananas, oranges, and coconuts for resale

loans.name: Binti

texts.en:
Mwanasha is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For more than a year, she has operated a fruits and vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the loan of 30,000 KES, she wants to purchase green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and onions for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables, tomatoes, potatoes and onions for resale.

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia appreciates the Kiva lenders for boosting her fruit and vegetable business. She also operates a retail shop in addition to the fruit and vegetable business.

She is requesting a loan of 50,000 KES to purchase sugar, corn flour, wheat flour, kerosene and detergents to sell. She looks forward to this financial support with gladness.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, corn flour, wheat flour, kerosene and detergents to sell.

loans.name: Dzame

texts.en:
This is Dzame She previously accessed a loan that she used for her business. Her earnings were a big help for her personal, household, and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for 10,000 KES  to buy sugar, wheat flour, tea leaves, and cooking oil for her business. Her profit from her business will definitely help her to provide for her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with happiness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy sugar, wheat flour, tea leaves, and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work.

She asks for a loan to re-stock items such as wheat flour, milk, cooking oil, detergent, maize flour, and sugar for her business. She is grateful for the financial support she has received.

loans.use: to re-stock items such as wheat flour, milk, cooking oil, detergent, maize flour, and sugar for her business.

loans.name: Mose

texts.en: Mose appreciates a previous kiva loan that improved her living standards. She requests a new  loan of 50,000 KES to purchase onions, tomatoes, vegetables, and potatoes for resale.  Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase onions, tomatoes, vegetables and potatoes for resale.

loans.name: Zabibu

texts.en:
Zabibu is a hard-working and enterprising woman. She is married, with one school-going child. She lives in a family house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Zabibu prepares juice and sells it to neighbors and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With the KES 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase a freezer for her business. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase a freezer for her business.

loans.name: Esha

texts.en:
Esha is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work.

She is asking for a loan to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, rice, beans, cooking oil, onions and charcoal for her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, rice, beans, cooking oil, onions and charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a hardworking woman with one school-going child. She lives in her own house that has electricity but not piped water.

Halima wants to start a new business of selling water. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 KES to pay for labor costs and purchase pipes for her business. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to pay for labor costs and purchase pipes for her business.

loans.name: Uchi

texts.en:
Uchi is a married woman who has been blessed with four school-going children. She lives in her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Uchi operates a food kiosk business, selling from her home to her neighbors and villagers. Her greatest monthly challenge is the high cost of transportation.

Uchi wants to pay school fees for her children to enable their continuous learning.
She is requesting for a loan of KES 30,000 to pay school fees for her children. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha is a married woman with two children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water.

She has operated a beauty salon business for the past three years, operating at the market for passers by and town dwellers. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the loan, she is requesting that she wants to stock her beauty salon business with shampoo and conditioner,hair braids, and treatments. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to buy shampoo and conditioner,hair braids, and treatments.

loans.name: Prudence

texts.en: Prudence is a hardworking woman who strives to support her family. She appreciates the previous loan, which helped her to purchase food consumables for her business. Again, she comes to you requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to buy wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and salt for her business. In addition, she raises chickens and boosts her income through the profits she gets out of the sales.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and salt for her business.

loans.name: Bendera

texts.en:
Bendera, 38, is married with three school-going children. They live in their own house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She operates a poultry selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passers-by. She faces a major challenge of disease outbreak.

With the loan she is requesting (KES 50,000), she wants to purchase medicine and food for her chicks. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase medicine and food for her chicks.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is married with five children, four of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. 

She operates a car wash business and she faces a major challenge of competition in her business.  Her dream is to establish a rental house in the near future. 

With the 40,000 KES she wants to purchase spare parts for her washing machine for work continuity. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for her washing machine for work continuity.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam who lives in the coastal region of Kenya, is a very hardworking and enterprising woman. She thanks Kiva lenders for their financial support.

She is requesting a loan of 40,000 KES to pay school fees for her children. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Mati

texts.en:
Mati is a married woman with six children, all under her care. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She wants to start a vegetable and fruit selling business. Her major goal is to become a leading fruit vending business in the area to raise her profits.

For that reason, with the KSh 30,000, she wants to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruits such as oranges, mangoes, watermelons, and pawpaw. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruit

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema, 28, is married and has two children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a green grocery business. She sells to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge is seasonality of her products, which reduces her sales.  

With the KSh 20,000, she wants to purchase sacks of green vegetables, tomatoes and onions for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of green vegetables, tomatoes and onions for resale.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en: Amina is a hardworking and enterprising woman who lives in the Coastal region of Kenya. She joined Yehu to get financial support. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 KES to pay school fees for her children. She appreciates Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Mishi

texts.en: Mishi appreciates her previous Kiva loan, which improved her living standards. Besides the retail shop business, Mishi sells clothes and handbags. She is requesting a loan of KSH 20,000 to purchase bales of clothes and handbags for resale. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes and handbags for resale

loans.name: Rumana

texts.en:
This is Rumana. Her previous loan was a big help to her business since she managed to renovate her rental houses. 

Rumana wants to dig a well to enable her tenants to access water easily. She is requesting for a loan of KES 50,000 to pay for the labor costs of her well. She joined Yehu Microfinance Trust to get financial support.

loans.use: to pay for the labor costs of her well.

loans.name: Kadzo

texts.en: Kadzo is thankful for the help from Kiva and Yehu. The previous loan helped her to purchase cooking oil, sugar, baking powder and wheat flour for her business. She is again requesting a loan of KSh 40,000 to buy sugar, cooking oil, maize flour, salt, and wheat flour.

loans.use: to buy sugar, cooking oil, maize flour, salt, and wheat flour

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is asking for a loan because she believes that through it she will be able to improve her business. She would like to diversify her businesses. Her previous loan enabled her to to save money from her firewood business, and she also operates a food kiosk.

She is requesting a loan of 30,000 KES to purchase wheat flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil for her food stall.

Salama feels that she was able to make a good investment with her previous loan, which to date has allowed her to maintain her level of profits to help her family cover their personal expenses.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, rice, beans, and cooking oil for her food stall.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a married woman, 50 years old. She has six children, three of whom still attend school. She lives in a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Sarah operates a fruit and vegetable-selling stall. She sells at the market to town-dwellers and neighbors. She faces challenges of competition and seasonality in her business. 

With the KES 15,000 loan, she wants to purchase sacks of oranges, bananas, and green vegetables to resell. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing a retail shop in the future.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of oranges, bananas, and green vegetables to resell.

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha 44 years old and is a married woman with four kids, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children.

Mwanaisha operates a grocery stall, selling vegetables at the market to town dwellers and neighbors. She struggles with the high transportation cost getting to the market each day, since she buys goods in large quantity.

With the 40,000 KES in this loan, she wants to buy green vegetables, tomatoes, onions and mangoes to sell. She decided to join Yehu, Kiva's field partner, to access loans that would help her boost her business.

loans.use: to buy green vegetables, tomatoes, onions and mangoes to sell.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a hardworking and enterprising woman who lives in the Coastal region of Kenya. Her previous loan was a big help in a clothes-selling business.

Beside the clothes selling business, she sells dried fish.

Rehema is requesting a loan of ksh. 50,000 to purchase sacks of dried fish for her business. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of dried fish for her business.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
This is Fatuma. Her previous loan was a big help to her business. She was able to purchase more clothes to sell.

Fatuma now wants to start selling water. She would like to have her water source in her home, so she is applying for a loan of 20,000 KES through Yehu to buy pipes and pay for labor.

Fatuma looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy pipes and pay for labor.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married woman with children who still attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity, but not piped water.

Elizabeth has operated a kiosk retail shop business for the past year, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar.  In her business, she faces a major challenge with competition. With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour, and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour, and wheat flour.

loans.name: Omar

texts.en:
Omar works hard to support his family economically. The previous loan helped him to buy spare parts for his motorcycle. 

In addition, he has a food-selling shop which helps him to supplement his income. 

Here again he is requesting a loan of 35,000 Kenya Shillings (KES) to buy food consumables for his shop to sell like soap, rice, milk, bread, and cooking oil.

loans.use: to buy soap, rice, milk, bread, and cooking oil for his shop

loans.name: Tumu

texts.en:
Tumu is a married woman with three children all under her care. They own a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Tumu has a vegetable and fruit selling business. Her major goal is to become a leading fruit vending business in the area to raise her profits.

For that reason with the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase green vegetables, cabbages, sacks of oranges, mangoes, water melons, and pawpaw for her business. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables, cabbages, sacks of oranges, mangoes, water melons, and pawpaw

loans.name: Mwanarusi

texts.en:
Mwanarusi is a married woman with one child who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity, but not piped water.

Mwanarusi has operated a cosmetic business for the past two years. Her potential customers are women. With the 20,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase body lotion, beauty soaps, jewelry, and chemical hair treatments for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase body lotion, beauty soaps, jewelry, and chemical hair treatments for resale.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a married woman with two school-going children. She lives at her own house that has no piped water but has electricity. 

Mwanakombo has operated a boutique shop for the past four years, and her potential customers are women. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation in her business. With the 20,000 KES, she wants to purchase clothes for her business. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase clothes for her business.

loans.name: Nadzua

texts.en:
Nadzua is married with five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

Nadzua operates a broom-selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With this 20,000 KES loan she wants to purchase brooms for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase brooms for sale.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret appreciates Kiva lenders for the financial support that improved her motorcycle business. She was able to generate more profits which she used to improve her living standards.

She is requesting for a loan of KSh 50,000 to pay school fees for her children. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Mwanaisha

texts.en:
Mwanaisha is married and has six children, all of whom are in school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a fish selling business for the last two years, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby persons. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.

With the 30,000 KES, she wants to purchase a freezer for her business. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to acquire financial services for her business.

loans.use: to purchase a freezer for her business.

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a hardworking and enterprising woman. She is a married mother of seven children; six go to school and one is underage. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mejumaa prepares dumplings using sugar, cooking oil, and wheat flour and sells to neighbors and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With the KES 10,000, she wants to purchase wheat flour, sugar, and cooking oil for her business. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, sugar, and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a married and has five children who attend school. She owns a house that has electricity, but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mejumaa has operated a fish selling business for the last five years, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. With this KES 50,000 loan, Mejumaa wants to purchase more stock of fish for her business. She decided to join Yehu to acquire financial services for her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of fish for her business.

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en: Mwanamisi appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards. She is requesting a loan of KES 30,000 to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.
