loans.use: to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a married man with six children. All of the children attend school. He owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past three years, he has operated a retail shop selling to his neighbours and passersby. He mentioned price fluctuations as his major business challenge. He dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

He decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access loans to boost his business. With the 50,000 KES loan, he wants to purchase maize flour, sugar, kerosene, rice, beans, and cooking oil for resale.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, sugar, kerosene, rice, beans, and cooking oil for resale.

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu is a married mother of seven children, four in school and three adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

Saumu has operated a cashew nut selling business at the market for the past seven years, selling to passersby individuals and neighbors. She cited seasonality as her major challenge in the business.

With the 30,000 KES, she wants to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is a married woman with one child who goes to school. She owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over two years Mercy has operated a fruits and vegetables stall by her home from which she sells her produce to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.

Mercy decided to join Yehu to access its business loans. She is applying for a 20,000 KES loan to buy greater amounts of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes and onions to sell. She would like to have her own grocery store in the future.

loans.use: to buy greater amounts of produce to sell.

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en:
Zaituni is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over five years, she has operated a fruits and vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the KES 40,000, she wants to purchase stocks of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes, and onions for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of green vegetables, fruits, tomatoes, potatoes, and onions for resale.

loans.name: Mariamu

texts.en:
Mariamu is a married mother of five children who are in school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. 

Mariamu has operated a cashew nut selling business at the market for the past twelve years, selling to passersby and neighbors. She cited seasonality as her major challenge in the business.

With the KES 10,000, she wants to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cashew nuts for resale.

loans.name: Mupa

texts.en: Mupa appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. Beside the small store she operates, she keeps livestock, such as cattle. She would like to apply for a loan of KES 50,000 to buy more cows for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more cows for her business.

loans.name: Mwaka

texts.en:
Mwaka is a widowed woman with three adult children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Mwaka has operated a business selling clothing for the past fifteen years. She sells at the market to dwellers, passersby, and neighbors. She faces inflation as her major business challenge. 

She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access loans to boost her business. With the 20,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase bales of clothing for resale.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothing for resale.

loans.name: Maselina

texts.en:
Maselina is a widowed woman with four children. Three are adults and one is in college. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past six years, she has operated a food kiosk business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 50,000 loan, she wants to purchase more stock for her business and pay school fees for her child. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase more stock for her business and pay school fees for her child.

loans.name: Damaris

texts.en:
Damaris, a hardworking and enterprising woman who lives in the coastal region of Kenya, is a married mother of three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

For the past six years, Damaris has operated a chemist shop, selling to her neighbours and passersby. Price fluctuations are her major challenge. 

With this Kshs 20,000 loan, Damaris wants to purchase more medicines for her business and pay her children's school fees. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her enterprise.

loans.use: to purchase more medicines for her business and pay her children's school fees.

loans.name: Zuhura

texts.en:
Zuhura is a hardworking and enterprising woman who practices livestock farming.  Beside keeping poultry, she also keeps goats and cows.  

She thanks Kiva lenders for her previous loan that expanded her poultry farm.  

She is requesting for a loan of ksh.50,000 to purchase more goats, cows and to pay for transportation costs for her business.She joined Yehu for financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more goats,cows and to pay for transportation costs for her business.

loans.name: Alina

texts.en:
Alina is grateful for her previous loan that enabled her expand her vegetable stall business.  

She is now requesting for a loan of ksh.30,000 to pay school fees for her children.She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Mesalim

texts.en:
Mesalim is a married woman. She has five children, four of whom attend school and one who is underage. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mesalim operates a maize selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality.

With the KES 40,000 she wants to purchase sacks of maize for resale and pay for transportation costs. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize for resale.

loans.name: Tabu

texts.en:
Tabu is a married woman with two children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a food kiosk business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 15,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase maize flour, beans, cooking oil and wheat flour for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, beans, cooking oil and wheat flour for her business

loans.name: Kahasu

texts.en:
Kahasu is a widowed woman with six children, five of whom go to school plus one who is still too young for school. They live in their own house with neither electricity nor running water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Kahasu has operated a fruit and vegetable stall business for the past ten years. She sells from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a miniature green grocer in the future.

With the loan of KES 50,000 from Yehu, she wants to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, tomatoes for resale and use the rest of the money to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes, tomatoes for resale and use the rest of the money to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is married with two children who are not in school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a basket weaving business, selling woven baskets from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces seasonality as her major challenge in the business.

With the KShs 20,000, she wants to purchase bundles of palm leaves and pay transportation costs. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase palm leaves and pay transportation costs.

loans.name: Umazi

texts.en: Umazi appreciates her previous kiva loan that improved her living standard. She is requesting for a loan of ksh.10,000 to purchase more palm leaves for her business. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more palm leaves for her business.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a single mother of two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees for her children

For over two years, she has operated an open-air food selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of business. 

With the Kshs 25,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat for use in the business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and cooking fat

loans.name: Nzadze

texts.en: Nzadze is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work. She is asking for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received from Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Mbodze

texts.en:
Mbodze is a married woman with seven children, five of whom attend school.  One is an adult and one is underage. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past six years, she has operated a food stall and a shoe-selling business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

She is asking for a loan to improve her food stall business. With the Kshs 30,000, she wants to purchase maize flour, potatoes, wheat flour, sugar, and vegetables for her business.She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, wheat flour, sugar,and vegetables for her business

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is a hardworking woman who lives at the Coastal region of Kenya. She is enterprising and has been able to improve her living standard.

She operates a mat and basket weaving business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality as her major challenge in the business.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase palm leaves for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase palm leaves for her business

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at her own house that has no electricity or piped water.

Jackline has operated a beauty salon business for the past three years, rendering services to passersby and town dwellers. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to buy shampoo, conditioner, braids and hair treatment for her salon business. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to buy shampoo, conditioner, braids and hair treatment for her salon business.

loans.name: Honner

texts.en:
Honner is a single woman and has been blessed with four kids who attend school. She lives in her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her four kids. 

She has operated a fish selling business for over 10 years. She mentioned seasonality as a challenge in the business and she dreams of becoming a wholesaler of fish in the future. 

With the KShs 25,000, she wants to purchase sacks of fish for resale. She joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fish for resale.

loans.name: Carol

texts.en:
Carol is a single mother of two children, who attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past one year, she has operated a clothes selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of stiff competition in her business. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 20,000, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Bint

texts.en:
Bint appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

Beside the food kiosk she operates, Bint operates a motorcycle business. She would like to apply for a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase a new motorbike for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase a new motorbike for her business.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is married with six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

She operates a groundnuts business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.  Her dream is to establish a wholesale shop in the near future. 

With the KES 20,000, she wants to purchase five sacks of groundnuts for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase five sacks of groundnuts for sale.

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a hard-working and enterprising woman who lives in the coastal region of Kenya. She is married and is a mother of five children who are in school. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family.

For the past 12 years, Mwanajuma has operated a chemist shop business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major challenge. 

With the KES 40,000 loan, Mwanajuma wants to purchase antibiotics and human medicine to resell. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase antibiotics and human medicine to resell.

loans.name: Wilbroda

texts.en:
Wilbroda is married and has two children. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. 

She operates a health clinic business, providing services to the people in that area. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the KES 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase drugs for her health clinic. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase drugs for her health clinic business

loans.name: Goldmayaor

texts.en:
Goldmayaor is a divorced mother of two children. Both of her children attend school. She owns a house, which has neither electricity nor piped water.

She operates a business selling dagaa (small fish). She sells at the market, to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase seven sacks of dagaa for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans, to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase seven sacks of dagaa for sale.

loans.name: Nchinyezi

texts.en:
Nchinyezi is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for the family and school fees. 

For the past five years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passers-by. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 20,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase maize flour, wheat flour, cooking oil, and beans for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, wheat flour, cooking oil, and beans for resale.

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a widower and has three children, all of whom go to school. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

Mejumaa has operated a coconut selling business for the past ten years, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. 

With the loan she is requesting she wants to purchase sacks of coconuts for resale and to pay school fees for her children. She decided to join Yehu to access loans for financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of coconuts for resale and pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Emmaculate

texts.en:
This is Emmaculate. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy more cosmetics items in her business. She has been in this business for years now, and it keeps on growing. 

She would like to apply for a loan for 50,000 KES, to buy cosmetics products, body creams, body lotions and body sprays for her business. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics products, body creams, body lotions and body sprays for her business.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is married and has one child who is still underage.  She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is household consumables.

For over five years, she has operated a tailoring business, making garments for both men and women and also curtains. She cites seasonality as her major challenge. 

With the KES 15,000 she wants to purchase cloth materials and sewing threads for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and sewing threads for her business

loans.name: Mesaid

texts.en:
Mesaid appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

Mesaid operates a food stall. She would like to apply for a loan of KES 50,000 to buy more stocks of wheat flour, cooking oil, salt and charcoal for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of wheat flour, cooking oil, salt and charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a married mother of four children, all of whom attend school. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past ten years, she has operated a clothes selling business, selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of high cost of transportation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 25,000 she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Musenya

texts.en:
Musenya is a married woman with two children who are still underage. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food.

Musenya operates a food making business, making constables like, beans, chapati (flat bread) for sale to school children. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase food items, maize flour, beans, cooking oil, sugar and vegetables for her business. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items, maize flour, beans, cooking oil, sugar and vegetables for her business.

loans.name: Nzingo

texts.en:
Nzingo is a married woman, living in a rental house which has electricity but not piped water. Her primary monthly expenses are food and school fees for her four children. She has been operating a firewood business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces stiff competition in her business from other charcoal operators.
 
With the 10,000 KES loan she wants to purchase more firewood for resale since it is yielding good profits for her. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more firewood for resale

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For over two years, she has operated a fruits and vegetable stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a grocery store in the future.

With the KES 30,000 loan she wants to purchase stock of green vegetables, bananas, tomatoes, potatoes and onions and for transportation costs. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock of green vegetables, bananas, tomatoes, potatoes and onions and for transportation costs

loans.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima thanks Kiva lenders for their financial support towards her business of selling goats. She managed to get extra income which she used to improve her living standards.

Beside the goat-selling business, Halima operates a cosmetics shop. She is requesting for a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase hair weaves, shampoos, and body lotions to resell. She joined Yehu Microfinance Trust to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase hair weaves, shampoos, and body lotions to resell.

loans.name: Kwekwe

texts.en: Kwekwe is a hardworking and enterprising woman who appreciates the financial support of Kiva lenders. Her previous loan was a big help to her business. She is requesting a loan of 40,000 KES to add more stock of juice flavors for her business. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to add more stock of juice flavors for her business

loans.name: Harusi

texts.en:
Harusi is a married mother of seven children, five of whom are adults, while two attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past year, Harusi has operated a kiosk shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. Seasonality is her major challenge. 

With this Kshs 20,000 loan, Harusi  wants to purchase sugar, wheat flour, sweets and salt for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her enterprise, and dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, wheat flour, sweets and salt for her business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: This is Elizabeth. She managed to purchase more building items to add more rooms to her rental houses. Beside the rental houses, she operates a vegetable stall. She is requesting a loan of KES 50,000, which she will use to purchase potatoes, vegetables, tomatoes and bananas, as well as transportation to her place of business. She looks forward to receiving this financial support.

loans.use: to pay for fruits, vegetables, and transportation

loans.name: Nyamvula

texts.en:
Nyamvula appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

She would like to apply for a loan of 20,000 Kenya Shillings (KES) to buy more stock of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and sugar for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more stock of wheat flour, maize flour, tea leaves, and sugar for her business.

loans.name: Wanzala

texts.en:
Wanzala is a hardworking and enterprising woman who lives in the coastal region of Kenya. For the past two years she has operated a café. Her customers include neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality as a major challenge.

Wanzala decided to join Yehu in order to access loans to boost her business. She is applying for a 30,000 KES loan to buy sugar, wheat and maize flour, cooking oil, rice and beans to make the food she sells.

loans.use: to buy ingredients to make the food she sells.

loans.name: Luvuno

texts.en: Luvuno appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She would like to apply for a loan of KSh 40,000 to buy more bales of clothes for resale. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Nzara

texts.en:
Nzara is married and has seven children, six of whom attend school and one is an adult. She lives at her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her children.

For the past two years, she has operated a bodaboda (motorcycle) transport business . Her potential customers are town dwellers. She cites high cost of maintenance as her major challenge.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase spare parts for her motorbike business. She joined Yehu to access loans to improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for her motorbike business.

loans.name: Kwekwe

texts.en:
Kwekwe lives in the coastal region of Kenya. 

For the past two years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 30,000, she wants to purchase maize flour, wheat flour, kerosene, sugar, rice and beans for resale. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, wheat flour, kerosene, sugar, rice and beans for resale.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en: Asha is grateful to Kiva lenders for her previous Kiva loan, which improved her living standards. She is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase more chicks for her business. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more chicks for her business

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with five children, all of whom are adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Fatuma wants to start a new business operating a kiosk shop, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KSh 20,000, she wants to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase sweets, biscuits, bread, milk, soft drinks, rice, beans, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en: Mwanasiti is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family thanks to her hard work. She is asking for a loan to buy more sacks of charcoal for her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en: Asha lives in the coastal region of Kenya. She is a hardworking and enterprising woman. For the past two years, she has operated a retail shop, selling to her neighbours and passers-by. She says seasonality and theft are her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future. With her KES 50,000 loan she wants to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking  oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour, rice, beans, and cooking  oil

loans.name: Mwanamisi

texts.en: Mwanamisi appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She would like to apply for a loan of KSh 30,000 to buy more stock of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more stock of wheat flour, maize flour, rice and sugar for her business

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a married woman and has nine children, seven in school and two adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

She has operated a fish-selling business for the last three years, selling at the market to her neighbors’ and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase fish for her business. She decided to join Yehu to acquire financial services for her business

loans.use: to purchase fish for her business

loans.name: Nzadze

texts.en:
Nzadze is a married woman with nine children, three in school and six adults. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past 11 years, Nzadze has been selling goats at the market to the general public. The main challenge for her business has been unstable market prices. 

She joined Yehu Microfinance Trust in order to gain access to funds.  She is requesting a loan of  KES 30,000 to purchase more goats.

loans.use: to purchase more goats.

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en: Chizi is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work. She is asking for a loan to expand her business by buying more goats. She is grateful for the new support she has received from Yehu and from Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy more goats for her business.

loans.name: Mwanangandu

texts.en:
Mwanangandu is a divorced woman with no children. She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

Mwanangandu has operated a fish selling business at the market for the past eight years, selling to her town dwellers and neighbors. She faces a major challenge of high cost of purchasing fish, especially during cold currents in the deep sea. 

Mwanangandu is requesting for a loan to purchase bundles of fish, cooking oil for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans at lower cost to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of fish, cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past two years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 20,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil, and potatoes for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil, and potatoes for her business.

loans.name: Zena

texts.en:
Zena is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work. Besides selling clothes, she also prepares food to sell.

She is asking for a loan to buy ingredients such as onions, cooking oil, tomatoes, beans and rice for her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as onions, cooking oil, tomatoes, beans and rice for her business.

loans.name: Najma

texts.en:
Najma is a married woman with three school-going children. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Najma operates a food-making business, making consumables like beans and chapati (flat bread) for sale to passersby and neighbours. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase food items such as rice, wheat flour, fish, and cooking oil for her business. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establishing a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items such as rice, wheat flour, fish, and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman and has six children, all of whom are adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a fish selling business for the last twenty years, selling at the market to her neighbors’ and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase fish, cooking oil, and firewood for her business. She decided to join Yehu to acquire financial services for her business

loans.use: to purchase fish, cooking oil, and firewood for her business

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She would like to apply for a loan of ksh.60,000 to purchase more lessos (women wrap) clothes for resale. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more lessos (women's wrap) clothes for resale.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en: Mwanasha appreciates her previous kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. Beside the fish selling business, she prepares food for her customers. She is requesting for a loan of ksh.80,000 to purchase food ingredients such as cooking oil, onions, tomatoes, rice, beans for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase food ingredients such as cooking oil, onions, tomatoes, rice, and beans for her business.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is married and has seven children who are adults. She lives at her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

For the past ten years, she has operated a bodaboda (motorcycle) transport business. Her potential customers are town dwellers. She cites the high cost of maintenance being her major challenge.

With the 80,000 KES, she wants to purchase another motorcycle to expand her business. She joined Yehu to access loans to improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase another motorcycle to expand her business.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha appreciates her previous loan that enabled her to make profits that she used in her vegetable selling business. Besides her vegetable selling business, she practices poultry farming.

She requests a loan of 100,000 KES to purchase chicks and chicken feed for her business. She appreciates Kiva and Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and chicken feed for her business.

loans.name: Mwanamwinyi

texts.en:
Mwanamwinyi is a married woman with six children, five in school and one under age. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwanamwinyi operates a food making business, making commodities like beans and chapati (flat bread) for sale to passersbys and neighbors. She has been in this business for the last six years.

With the 30,000 KES, she wants to purchase food items - beans, rice, wheat flour, cooking oil and sugar - for her business. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and to establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items - beans, rice, wheat flour, cooking oil and sugar - for her business.

loans.name: Bibi

texts.en: Bibi appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 KES to purchase bales of clothes and handbags for resale. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes and handbags for resale.

loans.name: Cicilia

texts.en:
This is Cicilia. She thanks Kiva lenders for their financial support that has enabled her to improve her business. Her previous loan was a big help to her charcoal-selling business. Beside the charcoal-selling business, Cicilia operates a retail shop.

She is requesting a loan of 22,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase more stock of soap, sugar and maize flour for resale. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of soap, sugar and maize flour for resale

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a married woman who has been blessed with six children who are adults. She lives at her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water.

Mariam has operated a firewood selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and villagers. Her greatest monthly challenge is the high cost of transportation.

She is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to purchase bundles of firewood for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood for resale.

loans.name: Mwanawani

texts.en:
Mwanawani is married with one child who is still underage. They live in their own house that has electricity and piped water. Mwanawani's greatest monthly expense is food.

Mwanawani has operated a fruit and vegetable stall for the past two years. She sells from her home to her neighbors, and she dreams of establishing a mini green grocer in the future. With the 50,000 KES, she wants to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes and tomatoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes and tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work. 

She is asking for a loan to purchase more stock of firewood and charcoal for her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of firewood and charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a married woman with three school going children. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mwanakombo operates a food making business, making comestibles like beans and chapati (flat bread) for sale to passersby and neighbours.

With the KES 20,000, she wants to purchase food items, wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar and charcoal for her business. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items, wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar and charcoal for her business

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

She would like to apply for a loan of KES 50,000 to buy more stock of charcoal for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to buy more stock of charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en: Mejumaa appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her clothing business and earn a higher income. She is now requesting a loan of 20,000 KES to purchase more women's wraps to resell. She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more women's wraps to resell.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is a married woman with one child who is still underage. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

For the past one year, she has operated a food stall business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 20,000 KES she wants to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking oil for her business.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is a married woman with two school-going children. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Salama has operated a food stall business for the past three years, selling to passersby and neighbours. She faces price fluctuation as her major challenge. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase beans, rice, wheat flour, cooking oil and sugar for resale. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establishing a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase beans, rice, wheat flour, cooking oil and sugar for resale

loans.name: Bidalla

texts.en:
Bidalla is a business woman who is very hardworking.  She is married with four children, all of whom are in school.  She lives in her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

Bidalla has operated a business selling charcoal and firewood for the past year. Her potential clients are neighbours and passersby. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future. 

With the 20,000 KES she wants to purchase bundles of firewood and twenty sacks of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood and twenty sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman and has been blessed with two kids who attend school. She lives at her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

She has a fish selling business, which has been operational for over two years. She mentioned seasonality as a challenge in the business but she dreams of becoming a wholesaler of fish in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of fish for resale. She joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fish for resale.

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Tatu is a married woman with eight school-going children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expenses are food for the family and school fees. 

For the past year, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentioned price fluctuation as her major challenge.  She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the 20,000 KES she wants to purchase sugar, biscuits, soaps, cooking oil and maize flour for resale. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, biscuits, soaps, cooking oil and maize flour for resale.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
Mwanasha is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a food stall business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She mentioned seasonality and theft as her major challenges. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 40,000 loan, she wants to purchase wheat flour, sugar, cooking oil and baking powder for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, sugar, cooking oil and baking powder for her business.

loans.name: Ningome

texts.en:
Ningome is a married woman with two school-going children. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Ningome operates a food production business. She makes consumables like beans and chapati (flat bread) and sells them to passers-by and neighbours. 

With the 30,000 KES loan, she wants to purchase utensils and food items such as wheat flour, cooking oil, and maize flour for her business. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establishing a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase utensils and ingredients such as wheat flour, cooking oil, and maize flour

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is still single and has no children. She owns a house, which has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Mwanasiti has operated a clothes-selling business for the past two years. She sells at the market, to town dwellers, passersby and neighbors. She faces a major challenge of inflation, in her business.

With the KES 30,000 loan, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans, to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale

loans.name: Mwanamkuu

texts.en:
Mwanamkuu is a hardworking and enterprising woman. She is a married mother of five children, one of whom is in school. The other four are adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Mwanamkuu cooks various food, such as flat bread and dumplings, and sells to neighbors and passersby. She cites seasonality as her major challenge.

With the Kshs 30,000 she wants to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil, and sugar for her business. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and establish a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, cooking oil, and sugar for her business.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a single lady. She lives in a rental house, which has electricity, but not piped water.

She has operated a business of selling household goods for the past two years, selling to her neighbours. She faces a major challenge of transportation, especially during rainy seasons.

With the KES 25,000 loan, she wants to purchase plates, ovens, cups, sufurias and kettles for the business. She dreams of expanding her business, and establishing another business in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase plates, ovens, cups, sufurias and kettles

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian is a married mother; she has three children who attend school. She lives at a rented house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her kids.

For the past three years, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of stiff competition in her business. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business, in the future.

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 20,000, she wants to purchase two bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans, to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase two bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is married with two school-going children. She lives in her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for the family and school fees.

Asha has operated a clothes selling business for the past three years. She sells door-to-door to town dwellers and neighbors. She faces a major challenge of inflation in her business. 

With the KES 30,000, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is married and has six children, four in school and two adults. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a fish-selling business for the last 13 years, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the KES 50,000 loan, she wants to purchase fish, cooking oil, and charcoal for her business. She decided to join Yehu Microfinance Trust to acquire financial services for her business

loans.use: to purchase fish, cooking oil, and charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Shida

texts.en:
Shida is single with nine children; five of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. 

She operates a business of selling palm wine to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.

With the KES 30,000, she wants to purchase raw materials for the preparation of wine. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for the preparation of palm wine.

loans.name: Philisia

texts.en:
Philisia  is a married woman with 4 kids, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that neither has electricity not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family and school fees.

Philisia operates a vegetable stall, selling to town dwellers and neighbors. She faces a challenge of a high cost of transportation to her place of operation. She dreams of expanding and establishing a wholesale business in the future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to pay school fees for her kids and buy onions, potatoes, vegetables, and fruits for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her kids and buy onions, potatoes, and vegetables for resale.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en:
This is Mwanasha. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy more items for her bread-making business. She has been in this business for years now, and it keeps on growing. 

She would like to apply for a loan of 30,000 Kshs to buy wheat flour, sugar, charcoal, and baking powder for her business. 

Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, sugar, charcoal, and baking powder for her business.

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia is a widowed woman, with four children who are not in school. They live at their own house, which has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

Rukia wants to start a new business, selling fruits and vegetables. She wants to sell from home to her neighbors. She dreams of establishing a mini-greengrocery, in the future.

With the KES 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes and tomatoes, for her business. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of green vegetables, onions, potatoes and tomatoes, for her business.

loans.name: Nyamawi

texts.en:
Nyamawi is a hardworking and enterprising man. He is still single, with no children. He owns a house, which has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food.

Nyamawi operates a business, selling car and bicycle spare parts. He cites price fluctuations as his major challenge.

With the KES 40,000 loan, he wants to purchase spare parts for his business, including car and bicycle tyres, engine parts, and car body parts. He joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts for his business, including car and bicycle tyres, engine parts, and car body parts.

loans.name: Mwanaulu

texts.en:
Mwanaulu is asking for a loan because she believes that through it, she will improve her business.
 
The previous loan enabled her to save money from her food-making business. She is requesting a loan of KES 20,000 to purchase food ingredients, such as cooking oil, onions, rice, tomatoes and beans, for her business.

She feels that she was able to make a good investment with her previous loan, which to date has allowed her to maintain her level of profits to help her family cover their personal expenses.

loans.use: to purchase food ingredients, such as cooking oil, onions, rice, tomatoes and beans, for her business.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a married woman and has five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity, but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. For the past ten years, she has operated her rental-house business. She faces a major challenge of maintenance on her rental houses.

With the KES 50,000 loan, she wants to purchase building materials for her rental houses. She decided to join Yehu to access loans, to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase building materials for her rental houses

loans.name: Mbeyu

texts.en:
Mbeyu is a hardworking and enterprising woman who is a divorced mother of nine children, who don't go to school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past ten years, she has practiced farming, growing various crops such as vegetables and tomatoes. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the KES 50,000, she wants to purchase seeds and pesticide for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and pesticide for her business.

loans.name: Richirani

texts.en:
Richirani is a hardworking and enterprising woman who is married with six school-aged children. She owns a house that does not have electricity or running water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food for the family.

For the past five years, she has grown onions, potatoes,vegetables, and tomatoes. She faces weather challenges  in her business. 

She wants to borrow 40,000 KES to hire a tractor to plough her land and purchase seeds for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to hire a tractor to plough her farm land and purchase seeds for her business.

loans.name: Dzame

texts.en:
This is Dzame.  She appreciates Kiva lenders for providing a previous loan that improved her living standards.   She was  able  to expand her motorcycle and fish businesses and earn a higher income.  Dzame also operates a grain business and she raises poultry.

She would like to apply for a loan of 100,000 KES to purchase chicks, beans,and maize for her business. 

She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase chicks, beans, and maize for her business.

loans.name: Naumi

texts.en:
Naumi is a married woman with no children. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

Naumi operates a business selling maize, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality.

With the KES 30,000 she wants to purchase sacks of maize for resale.  She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize for resale

loans.name: Rodah

texts.en:
Rodah is married and has three children who are in school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for the family and school fees.

For the past four years, she has operated a poultry selling business. She sells to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenges are high cost of transportation to her place of operation.

With the Ksh 10,000 she wants to purchase chicks and chicken feeds. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and chicken feeds.

loans.name: Mbeyu

texts.en:
Mbeyu is a married woman with seven children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest  monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mbeyu operates a cereal-selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality.

With the KES 21,000 she wants to purchase sacks of maize, beans, and rice for resale. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize, beans, and rice for resale.

loans.name: Kajumwa

texts.en:
Kajumwa is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

For the past three years, she has operated a shop kiosk business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She mentions price fluctuation as her major challenge. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future.

With this 35,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to purchase more stock of maize flour, wheat flour, beans and cooking oil for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of maize flour, wheat flour, beans and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Subira

texts.en: Subira appreciates her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. Beside selling coconuts, she has a shop kiosk that sells various items. She is requesting for a loan of ksh.10,000 to purchase stocks of maize flour, wheat flour, and beans for resale . She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of maize flour, wheat flour, and beans for resale

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en:
Chizi is a married woman.  She has six children who are adults. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food .

Chizi operates a cereal selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to purchase sacks of maize, beans, rice for resale.  She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of maize, beans, rice for resale

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica appreciates for her previous Kiva loan that improved her living standards and enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income. Beside a clothes selling business, she also sells fish. She is requesting for a loan of ksh.25,000 to purchase more fish for resale . She thanks Yehu for their financial support.

loans.use: to purchase fish for resale

loans.name: Omar

texts.en:
Omar operates a charcoal selling business, selling from home to neighbors and passersby. He faces stiff competition from other charcoal operators in his area.
 
With the KES 40,000, he wants to purchase twelve sacks of charcoal for resale. He decided to join Yehu, in order to access loans to boost his business. He appreciates the support.

loans.use: to purchase twelve sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She lives in her own house that neither has electricity nor piped water.  Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past 11 years she has been selling goats to the general public at the market. The main challenge for her business has been unstable market prices. 

She joined Yehu in order to gain access to funds.  She is requesting a loan of  40,000 KES to purchase more goats.

loans.use: to purchase more goats.

loans.name: Amisa

texts.en:
Amisa is married. They live at their own house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees for her kids. 

She has operated a water selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby.

With the loan she is requesting Kes 25,000 she wants to purchase a water pump for water drainage when selling. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a water pump for water drainage for her business.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is married with four children. They attend school which is the reason why Jane works hard. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. 

Jane operates a cafe business, making things like rice, tea, beans, and chapati (flat bread) to sell to passersby and neighbours. She also operates a motorcycle business. She cited seasonality as a major challenge.

With the 25,000 KES she wants to purchase stocks of goods like maize flour, wheat flour and rice, as well as spare parts for her motorcycle. She joined Yehu to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of goods like maize flour, wheat flour, and rice, as well as spare parts for her motorcycle.

loans.name: Asia

texts.en:
Asia has operated a spare parts selling business. She dreams of expanding her business to generate more income. 

With the loan that she is requesting of KES 30,000 she wants to purchase more spare parts for the business. She appreciates the Kiva and Yehu support.

loans.use: to purchase more spare parts for the business

loans.name: Harusi

texts.en: Harusi is a hardworking woman who has done her best to ensure her family is well sustained. She appreciates the previous loan she received and once again she is requesting a loan of Kshs 80,000 to purchase more timber for her business.

loans.use: to purchase timber to continue her business.

loans.name: Katsaka

texts.en: Katsaka appreciates the previous loans that helped her to boost her business. Here she comes to you to request a new loan of KES 50,000 to buy 18 sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.use: to buy 18 sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Roda

texts.en: Roda appreciates the previous loan that helped her to buy stuff for her workshop. Here again she requests another loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more nails of different inches, grease and paint for sale.

loans.use: to buy more nails of different inches, grease and paint for sale.

loans.name: Umi

texts.en:
Umi is married. She buys, packages and sells hardwood charcoal. At first she used to buy the charcoal already packaged, but she was able to expand her storage. She buys bags and polyurethane, packages the charcoal and sells to small businesses in the zone. 

She needs this loan to buy charcoal because she is increasing her number of customers and needs to increase her amount of charcoal to meet their demands. Her greatest desire is to provide an education for her children who attend school so that she can guarantee them a prosperous future.

loans.use: to buy more charcoal

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma appreciates Kiva lenders for her previous loan that improved her fruit and vegetable stall business and enabled her to get profits she used to improve her living standards.

She is requesting for a loan of KES 30,000 to pay school fees for her children.  She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo appreciates Kiva lenders for her previous loan that improved her clothes-selling business and enabled her to get profits she used to improve her living standards.

She is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to pay school fees for her children.  She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work.

She is asking for a loan to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, potatoes and cooking oil for her business. She is grateful for the new support she has received.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as wheat flour, potatoes and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy appreciates her previous loan that improved her living standards. Her previous loan enabled her to expand her business and earn a higher income.

She would like to apply for a loan of KES 30,000 to buy more chemicals of detergents for her business. She thanks Yehu for their financial support

loans.use: to buy more chemicals of detergents for her business.

loans.name: Nyiro

texts.en:
Nyiro appreciates Kiva lenders for her previous loan that improved her fruit and vegetable stall business and enabled her to get profits, which she used to improve her living standards.

She is requesting for a loan of KES 30,000 to pay school fees for her children. She joined Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Mayasa

texts.en:
Mayasa is a very hardworking and enterprising woman who says that she has been able to greatly increase her income and help her family, thanks to her hard work.

She thanks Kiva lenders for her previous loan, which enabled her earn a profit from her saloon business. Besides the saloon business, she also operates a food cafe preparing various meals.

She is asking for a loan to buy utensils, rice, beans and potatoes for her cafe business. She is grateful for the new support that she has received.

loans.use: to buy utensils, rice, beans and potatoes for her cafe business

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is married with three children, all of whom go to school. She lives in her own house, where she has electricity and running water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Rose has operated a shoe and handbag selling business for the past four years. She sells from home to her neighbors and passers-by. 

With this loan of KES 30,000 she wants to purchase sacks of shoes and handbags for resale. She decided to join Yehu for this financial support.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of shoes and handbags for resale.
